[[Abdulwahab Hussain]]
[[Hasan Mushaima]]
[[Saeed al-Shehabi]]
[[Ali Salman]] [[Abdullatif Al-Mahmood]] | leadfigures2 =[[Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa]]
[[Ian Henderson (police officer)|Ian Henderson]] | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = 40+ people killed (including one executed on charges of killing a soldier) }} {{History of Bahrain}} The '''1990s uprising in Bahrain''' ({{lang-ar|الانتفاضة التسعينية في البحرين}}) also known as the '''uprising of dignity'''{{cite news| title=Sheikh Abdul Amir al-Jamri |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=20 December 2006 |accessdate=5 June 2013| url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/dec/20/guardianobituaries.world |author=Phil Davison}} ({{lang-ar|انتفاضة الكرامة}}) was an [[rebellion|uprising]] in [[Bahrain]] between 1994 and 1999 in which [[left-wing politics|leftists]], [[liberalism|liberals]] and [[Islamism|Islamists]] joined forces to demand democratic reforms. The uprising caused approximately forty deaths and ended after [[Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa]] became the Emir of Bahrain in 1999[http://www.acrli.org/countryprofiles/bahrain.html "Country Profiles Bahrain"] The Arab Center for the Development of the Rule of Law and Integrity Retrieved 2010-12-01 and a referendum on 14–15 February 2001 massively supported the [[National Action Charter of Bahrain|National Action Charter]]. The uprising resulted in the deaths of around 40 civilians and at least one Bahraini soldier.[http://www.bna.bh/portal/news/453883 "التحالف الوطني ضد الإرهاب يزور أسر شهداء الواجب"]. Bahrain News Agency. 23 April 2011. Retrieved on 23 June 2012{{cite news|title=Bahrain: A Human Rights Crisis|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde11/016/1995/en/|newspaper=[[Amnesty International]]|date=25 Sep 1995}} ==Background== [[File:Essa bin Salman Al-Khalifa 1998.jpg|thumb|upright|The Amir, [[Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa]] dissolved the parliament and suspended the constitution in 1975.]] In 1971, Bahrain became independent from Britain and in 1973 the country had its first [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 1973|parliamentary election]]. However, two years later the constitution was suspended and the assembly dissolved by the Amir, [[Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa|Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa]] after it rejected the [[State Security Law in Bahrain|State Security Law]]. The act also known as "the precautionary law" was proposed by [[Ian Henderson (police officer)|Ian Henderson]]. It gave police wide arresting powers and allowed individuals to be held in prison without trial or charge for up to three years for mere suspicion "that they might be a threat to the state". Starting in August 1975, widespread arrests were conducted including members of the dissolved parliament. The "ruthless system of repression" launched by Henderson lasted for over twenty five years. Repeated allegations of systematic torture, arbitrary arrests of thousands and assassinations made by opposition activists and human rights groups were denied by Henderson who said he "has never been involved in torture nor has he ever ordered his officers to torture those who have been arrested".[[Adam Curtis]] (11 May 2012). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/adamcurtis/2012/05/if_you_take_my_advice_-_id_rep.html "If you take my advice - I'd repress them"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 27 June 2012. In 1992, a petition signed by 280 society leaders, including some of the dissolved parliament members called for the restoration of the national assembly. Initially, the government set up a thirty-member appointed "Shura council" assigned with "commenting" on government proposed legislation. Another petition the following month concluded that the newly formed council "does not replace the national assembly as a constitutional and legislative authority". A delegation of six members, half Sunnis and half Shias representing petition organizers met with the Amir who told them Shura council "was all [they] could expect".[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/45cafc9e2.html "Routine Abuse, Routine Denial: Civil Rights and the Political Crisis in Bahrain"]. [[Human Rights Watch]]. [[UNHCR]]. 1 January 2006. Retrieved 19 July 2012.{{cite news|title=Bahrain: A Human Rights Crisis|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde11/016/1995/en/|newspaper=[[Amnesty International]]|date=25 Sep 1995}} ==Aims== Like other uprisings during the 1990s, the uprising's stated aims were for democratic reform, and it was considered as the first movement in the Arab world where [[left-wing politics|leftists]], [[liberalism|liberals]] and [[Islamism|Islamists]] joined forces on a common ground calling for restoration of the dissolved parliament and suspended constitution. Although attempts were made to portray a totalitarian nature of an Islamic fundamentalist ideology, the events and the moderate discourse of their leaders attracted support from all human rights organizations (such as [[Amnesty International]], [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Article 19]], UN Human Rights Sub-Commission, etc.) as well as from members of parliament in the UK, France, USA and the EU. The final aim of the uprising was the reinstatement of the [[1973 Constitution of Bahrain|1973 constitution]] and respect of human rights in Bahrain, while preserving plurality of opinions in society. ==Main events== The uprising began in June 1994, with a picket by unemployed people in front of the ministry of labour. Over 1,500 demonstrator tried to organize a sit-in front of Ministry of Labor protesting the increasing rate of unemployment which had reached 15 percent. Riot police dispersed them using tear gas. Similar incidents occurred in August and September. Another petition was launched, this time it was open to all citizens. Organizers said they collected over 20,000 signatures most of whom were Shia. In November, hundreds of Shia protested against a charity marathon. The route of the marathon was through some Shia villages, who considered the female dressings offensive. Reportedly, some protesters threw stones on the marathon, which prompted security forces to conduct a number of arrests. The following month [[Ali Salman]], a protest leader, was arrested after being accused of inciting the incident. The arrest sparked further protests and violence in Manama and [[Sitra]]. Some protesters used Molotov cocktails to attack "police stations, banks and commercial properties". On the other hand, riot police used tear and rubber bullets, sometimes "fired at street level and from helicopters". It was also reported that police used live ammunition on some occasions. By December, the number of detainees was between 500 and 600 according to the US Embassy. A number of opposition leaders, including Ali Salman were exiled in January 1995. Protests and arrests continued amid some government statements of releasing prisoners. In February the government said only 300 remain in prison, while activists said the number was as high as 2000. The level of violence and arrests increased again in March and April. [[Abdul Amir al-Jamri]], the leader of the uprising was arrested on 1 April along with other protest leaders such as [[Abdulwahab Hussain]] and [[Hassan Mushaima]]. One month after their arrest, the government started jailhouse negotiations with opposition leaders. About twenty one-or-two-hour meetings were conducted in four months between activists one side and Henderson, his deputy; [[Adel Flaifel]] or [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|Minister of Interior]] on the other side. An agreement named "the Initiative"{{ar icon}} [http://www.alwasatnews.com/967/news/read/460775/1.html "عبدالوهاب حسين"]. ''[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al Wasat]]''. 30 April 2005. Retrieved 23 May 2012. was reached in which opposition leaders would calm people in exchange for releasing all of those not convicted in courts. The government reportedly agreed that at a later stage after establishment of security, it would start a political dialogue with opposition. Initially, protests paused, however they resumed after the government denied such an agreement existed. In December 1995 and January 1996, two bombs exploded in a shopping mall and a hotel without causing any casualties. Opposition leaders were arrested. No charges were filed against them (as of May 2007). Bombings continued in the following months collecting the lives of eight people. The number of deaths by this time reached twenty four, including several deaths while in police custody due to alleged torture as well as three security forces. In May, a protester was sentenced to death penalty for allegedly killing a policeman. During this period, arrests increased, especially among women and children. In June, the government said it had detected a network called the "military wing of Hizb AllahBahrain". The government alleged it was backed by Iran and had caused the unrest. The claim that "Hizb Allah" existed in Bahrain was described by [[Human Rights Watch]] as lacking any credibility, however the report noted the influence of Iran during that period. The uprising was characterized by extreme forms of suppression, riots, stoning and bomb attacks. Over forty people were killed, mostly by the security forces. Most of the events of the uprising took place in Shia villages and towns; there was a strong religious component in the violence. The rhetoric of the pro-government quarters attempted to stain the image of the uprising, but at the end, the situation had to improve following the longest ever uprising in the history of Bahrain. ==Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa and the National Action Charter== The violence generally subsided after King [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]] carried out political reforms after he ascended to the throne in 1999. On 14 and 15 February 2001, the [[National Action Charter of Bahrain|National Action Charter]] was overwhelmingly approved by Bahrainis, with 98.4% in favour.{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Country Theme: Elections: Bahrain|work=|publisher=[[United Nations Development Program|UNDP]]-Programme on Governance in the Arab Region|year=2011|url=http://www.pogar.org/countries/theme.aspx?t=3&cid=2|format=|doi=|accessdate=2011-02-09|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wNSNDw42?url=http://www.pogar.org/countries/theme.aspx?t=3&cid=2|archivedate=2011-02-09|deadurl=yes|df=}} ==See also== *[[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)]] *[[History of Bahrain]] *[[Torture in Bahrain]] *[[Human rights in Bahrain]] *[[Bahrain Freedom Movement]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == *[[Abdulhadi Khalaf|Khalaf, Abdulhadi]] (1998). [https://web.archive.org/web/20060716180006/http://www.hf.uib.no/smi/pao/khalaf.html Contentious politics in Bahrain: From ethnic to national and vice versa]. University of Lund. *Fakhro, Munira A. 1997. "The Uprising in Bahrain: An Assessment". In ''The Persian Gulf at the Millennium: Essays in Politics, Economy, Security, and Religion'', eds. Gary G. Sick and Lawrence G. Potter: 167–188. New York: St. Martin’s Press. {{ISBN|0-312-17567-1}} *Bahry, Louay. ''The Socioeconomic Foundations of the Shiite Opposition in Bahrain''. Mediterranean Quarterly 11.3 (2000) 129–143. *Al-Mdaires, Falah. Shi'ism and Political Protest in Bahrain. Domes. Milwaukee: Spring 2002. Vol. 11, Iss. 1; pg. 20 *Wiktorowicz, Quintan ed ''Islamic Activism, A Social Theory Approach'' Indiana University Press, 2004 == External links == [https://web.archive.org/web/20070921075130/http://www.alwaqt.com/art.php?aid=59587 2], [https://web.archive.org/web/20110707121553/http://www.alwaqt.com/art.php?aid=59883 3], {{Redirect|The last trump|the fictional short story|The Last Trump}} {{Bible chapter|letname=1 Corinthians 15|previouslink= 1 Corinthians 14 |previousletter= chapter 14 |nextlink= 1 Corinthians 16 |nextletter= chapter 16 |book= [[First Epistle to the Corinthians]] |biblepart=[[New Testament]] | booknum= 7 |category= [[Pauline epistles]] | filename= POxy1008 (1Co 7.33-8.4).jpg |size=250px | name=Papyrus 15, 3rd century |caption=
1 Corinthians 7:33–8:4 in [[Papyrus 15]], written in the 3rd century
}} [[Image:Signorelli Resurrection.jpg|right|thumb|400px|''Resurrection of the Flesh'' (c. 1500) by [[Luca Signorelli]] – based on 1 Corinthians 15: 52: "the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed." Chapel of San Brizio, Duomo, Orvieto ]] '''1 Corinthians 15''' is the fifteenth chapter of the [[First Epistle to the Corinthians]] by [[Paul the Apostle]]. The first eleven verses contain the earliest account of the [[resurrection appearances of Jesus]] in the [[New Testament]]. The rest of the chapter stresses the primacy of the resurrection for [[Christianity]]. Readings from the text are given at funerals in the Catholic Church – where mourners are assured of the "sure and certain expectation of the resurrection to a better life".Catholic Church. (1998). ''Lectionary for mass, second typical edition, introduction'' (Liturgy documentary series, 1). Washington, D.C.: United States Catholic Conference. ==Text== * The original text is written in [[Koine Greek]]. * Some most ancient manuscripts containing this chapter are: ** [[Codex Vaticanus]] (AD 325–350) ** [[Codex Sinaiticus]] (AD 330–360) ** [[Papyrus 123]] (4th century; extant: verses 3–6) ** [[Codex Alexandrinus]] (c. AD 400–440) ** [[Codex Ephraemi Rescriptus]] (c. AD 450; extant: verses 41–58). ** [[Codex Freerianus]] (c. 450 M; extant: verses 3, 15, 27–28, 38–39, 49–50) ** [[Codex Claromontanus]] (c. AD 550) * [[Chapters and verses of the Bible|This chapter is divided into]] 58 verses. == Structure == The [[New King James Version]] organises this chapter as follows: * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:1–11|NKJV}} = The Risen Christ, Faith’s Reality * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:12–19|NKJV}} = The Risen Christ, Our Hope * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:20–28|NKJV}} = The Last Enemy Destroyed * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:29–34|NKJV}} = Effects of Denying the Resurrection * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:35–49|NKJV}} = A Glorious Body * {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:50–58|NKJV}} = Our Final Victory ==Resurrection of Jesus: 1–11== The chapter begins with the statement of the Good News, received by Paul from the ascended Jesus Christ. Paul reveals the significance of the death, burial, and Resurrection of Jesus Christ and that if we believe this message that we are saved. The account of the [[Resurrection of Jesus|Resurrection]] appearances of Jesus in verses 3–7 appears to be an early pre-Pauline [[creed|creedal statement]].Neufeld, ''The Earliest Christian Confessions'' (Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 1964) p. 47; Reginald Fuller, ''The Formation of the Resurrection Narratives'' (New York: Macmillan, 1971) p. 10 ({{ISBN|0281024758}}); Wolfhart Pannenberg, ''Jesus – God and Man'' translated Lewis Wilkins and Duane Pribe (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1968) p. 90 ({{ISBN|0664208185}}); Oscar Cullmann, ''The Early Church: Studies in Early Christian History and Theology'', ed. A. J. B. Higgins (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1966) p. 64; Hans Conzelmann, ''1 Corinthians'', translated James W. Leitch (Philadelphia: Fortress 1975) p. 251 ({{ISBN|0800660056}}); Bultmann, ''Theology of the New Testament'' vol. 1 pp. 45, 80–82, 293; R. E. Brown, ''The Virginal Conception and Bodily Resurrection of Jesus'' (New York: Paulist Press, 1973) pp. 81, 92 ({{ISBN|0809117681}}) The antiquity of the creed has been located by most biblical scholars to no more than five years after Jesus' death, probably originating from the Jerusalem apostolic community.Wolfhart Pannenberg, ''Jesus – God and Man'' translated Lewis Wilkins and Duane Pribe (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1968) p. 90 ({{ISBN|0664208185}}); Oscar Cullmann, ''The Early church: Studies in Early Christian History and Theology'', ed. A. J. B. Higgins (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1966) p. 66–66; R. E. Brown, ''The Virginal Conception and Bodily Resurrection of Jesus'' (New York: Paulist Press, 1973) pp. 81 ({{ISBN|0809117681}}); Thomas Sheehan, ''First Coming: How the Kingdom of God Became Christianity'' (New York: Random House, 1986) pp. 110, 118 ({{ISBN|0394511980}}); Ulrich Wilckens, ''Resurrection'' translated A. M. Stewart (Edinburgh: Saint Andrew, 1977) p. 2 ({{ISBN|071520257X}}); Hans Grass, ''Ostergeschen und Osterberichte'', Second Edition (Gottingen: Vandenhoeck und Ruprecht, 1962) p. 96; Grass favors the origin in Damascus. Based on linguistic analysis, the version received by Paul seems to have included verses 3b–6a and 7.{{cite journal |first=Kirk R. |last=MacGregor |title=1 Corinthians 15:3b–6a, 7 and the Bodily Resurrection of Jesus |journal=Journal of the Evangelical Theological Society |volume=49 |issue=2 |year=2006 |pages=225–34 |url=https://www.galaxie.com/article/10572}} The creed has been deemed to be historically reliable and is claimed to preserve a unique and verifiable testimony of the time.Hans von Campenhausen, "The Events of Easter and the Empty Tomb," in ''Tradition and Life in the Church'' (Philadelphia: Fortress, 1968) p. 44Archibald Hunter, ''Works and Words of Jesus'' (1973) p. 100 ({{ISBN|0334018064}}) In dissent from the majority view, [[Robert M. Price]] and Hermann Detering, writing in the [[Journal of Higher Criticism]] (edited by Price) argued that 1 Corinthians 15:3–7 was not an early Christian creed written within five years of Jesus' death. Price {{cite journal |url=http://depts.drew.edu/jhc/rp1cor15.html |title=Apocryphal Apparitions: 1 Corinthians 15:3–11 as a Post-Pauline Interpolation |first=Robert M |last=Price |authorlink=Robert M. Price |year=1995 |journal=Journal of Higher Criticism |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=69–99}} and Detering{{cite book|title=The Falsified Paul|page=3|author=Herman Detering}} denied that Paul wrote the verses and believed they were an [[Interpolation (manuscripts)|Interpolation]] possibly dating to as far back as the beginning of the 2nd century. Price said that "The pair of words in verse 3a, "received / delivered" (''paralambanein'' / ''paradidonai'') is, as has often been pointed out, technical language for the handing on of rabbinical tradition". According to Price, this (supposedly interpolated) text contradicts Paul's tale of conversion described in Galatians 1:13–24 which explicitly denies that Paul had been taught the gospel of Christ by any man, but rather by Jesus himself. However, many commentators have the view that Paul "received" this from Jesus.{{cite book|title=[[Commentary Critical and Explanatory on the Whole Bible]]|author1=[[Robert Jamieson (minister)|Robert Jamieson]]|author2=[[A. R. Fausset]]|author3=[[David Brown (Free Church of Scotland)|David Brown]]|year=1871}} They point to 1 Cor. 11:23 as evidence of this idea.''Commentary Critical and Explanatory on the Whole Bible'' (1871), commentary on 1 Corinthians 15:3. "For I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you, That the Lord Jesus the same night in which he was betrayed took bread..." (1 Corinthians 11:23, (KJV) ) The Greek words for "received / delivered" are the same here as in 1 Corinthians 15:3. Against these scholars, [[Geza Vermes]] defends the majority view in ''The Resurrection''. Vermes says that the words of Paul are "a tradition he has inherited from his seniors in the faith concerning the death, burial and resurrection of Jesus".Geza Vermes (2008) ''The Resurrection''. London, Penguin: 121–2 ({{ISBN|0739499696}}; {{ISBN|978-0141030050}}) [[Gary R. Habermas]] argues, "Essentially all critical scholars today agree that in Corinthians 15:3–8, Paul records an ancient oral tradition(s) that summarizes the content of the Christian gospel,"{{cite book |title=To Everyone an Answer: A Case for the Christian Worldview |editor1=[[Francis J. Beckwith]] |editor2=[[William Lane Craig]] |editor3=[[J. P. Moreland]] |publisher=InterVarsity Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0830877508 |page=182}} in which Paul "uses the explicit language of oral transmission," according to [[Donald Hagner]].{{cite book |title=The New Testament: A Historical and Theological Introduction |chapter=Part 2.7. The Origin and Reliability of the Gospel Tradition |author=[[Donald Hagner]] |publisher=Baker Books |year=2012 |isbn=1441240403}} In other words, Paul's account has been described by scholars as "the very early tradition that was common to all Christians",{{cite web |url=http://ntwrightpage.com/2016/04/05/early-traditions-and-the-origins-of-christianity/ |title=Early Traditions and the Origins of Christianity |author=[[N.T. Wright]] |publisher=NTWrightPage}} as "a sacred tradition",{{cite book |title=Lord Jesus Christ: Devotion to Jesus in Earliest Christianity |author=[[Larry W. Hurtado]] |publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing |year=2005 |isbn=978-0802831675 |page=71}} and contained in "the oldest strata of tradition".{{cite book |title=Perspectives on Scripture and Tradition: Essays in Honor of Dale Moody |editor=Robert L. Perkins |author=Dale Moody |publisher=Mercer University Press |year=1987 |isbn=978-0865543058 |page=109}} According to Paul's [[Epistle to the Galatians]] he had previously met two of the people mentioned in these verses as witnesses of the resurrection: [[James, brother of Jesus|James the Just]] and [[Saint Peter|Cephas/Peter]]:
Then after three years, I went up to Jerusalem to get acquainted with Cephas and stayed with him fifteen days. I saw none of the other apostles – only James, the Lord's brother. I assure you before God that what I am writing you is no lie. ({{bibleref2|Galatians|1:18–20}})
Moreover, even skeptical scholars agree that the creed in 1 Corinthians 15 is not an interpolation but was a creed formulated and taught at a very early date after Jesus' death. [[Gerd Lüdemann]], a skeptic scholar, maintains that "the elements in the tradition are to be dated to the first two years after the crucifixion of Jesus... not later than three years..."{{cite book|title=The Resurrection of Jesus|author=Gerd Lüdemann|year=1994|pages=38}} [[Michael Goulder]], another skeptic scholar, states that it "goes back at least to what Paul was taught when he was converted, a couple of years after the crucifixion".{{cite book|title=The Baseless Fabric of a Vision (as quoted in Gavin D'Costa's Resurrection Reconsidered, p. 48)|author=Michael Goulder|year=1996}} ===Verse 5=== : ''And that he was seen of Cephas, then of [[Twelve apostles|the twelve]]:''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:5|KJV}} ===Verse 6=== : ''After that He was seen by over five hundred brethren at once, of whom the greater part remain to the present, but some have fallen asleep.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:6|NKJV}} ===Verse 7=== : ''After that He was seen by James, then by all the apostles.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:7|NKJV}} This was probably [[James, brother of Jesus]].[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/jfb/1_corinthians/15.htm Jamieson-Fausset-Brown Bible Commentary on 1 Corinthians 15], accessed 11 April 2017 ===Verse 8=== : ''Then last of all He was seen by me also, as by one born out of due time.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:8|NKJV}} === Verse 9 === : ''For I am the least of the apostles, that am not meet to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:9|KJV}} ==Resurrection of the dead: 12–58== ===Jesus and the believers 12–19=== In verses 12–19, St Paul, in response to some expressed doubts of the Corinthian congregation, whom he is addressing in the letter, adduces the fundamental importance of the [[Resurrection of the dead|resurrection]] as a Christian doctrine. Through those verses, Paul is stressing the importance of the resurrection of Jesus Christ and its relevance to the core of Christianity. Paul rebukes the Corinth Church by saying if Jesus did not resurrect after the crucifixion, then there is no point in the Christianity faith (1 Cor 15:12–19 ESV). === Verse 17 === : ''And if Christ be not raised, your faith is vain; ye are yet in your sins.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:17|KJV}} ===Verses 20–28: the last enemy=== In verses 20–28, Paul states that [[Second Coming|Christ will return in power]] and put his "enemies under his feet" (25) and even death, "the last enemy", shall be destroyed: : ''The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:26|KJV}} ===Verse 29: baptism for the dead=== : ''Else what shall they do which are baptized for the dead, if the dead rise not at all? why are they then baptized for the dead?''{{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|15:29|KJV}} In verse 29 Paul notes that at Corinth there existed a practice whereby a living person would be [[Baptism for the dead|baptized]] instead of some convert who had recently died. [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Mormons]] interpret this passage to support their practice of [[Baptism for the dead]]. This principle of vicarious work for the dead is an important work of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] in the [[dispensation of the fulness of times]]. This interpretation is rejected by all other [[denominations of Christianity]]. {{Citation | title = LCMS Frequently Asked Questions: Other Denominations | publisher = Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod | ref = none}}{{Citation | title = Vatican Warns of Mormon 'Baptism of the Dead' | url = http://www.catholic.org/news/national/story.php?id=27825 | publisher = Catholic Online | accessdate = July 3, 2016 | ref = none}}{{Citation | title = Receive Guidelines for Ministering to Mormons Who Seek to Become United Methodists | url = http://www.umc.org/what-we-believe/receive-guidelines-for-ministering-to-mormons-who-seek-to-become-united-met | publisher = United Methodist Church | accessdate = July 3, 2016 | ref = none}} Teignmouth Shore, writing in [[Charles Ellicott|Ellicott]]'s ''Commentary for Modern Readers'', notes that "there have been numerous and ingenious conjectures as to the meaning of this passage. The only tenable interpretation is that there existed amongst some of the Christians at Corinth a practice of baptising a living person in the stead of some convert who had died before that sacrament had been administered to him. Such a practice existed amongst the [[Marcionites]] in the second century, and still earlier amongst a sect called the Corinthians."[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/ellicott/1_corinthians/15.htm Ellicott's Commentary for Modern Readers on 1 Corinthians 15], accessed 12 April 2017 The [[Jerusalem Bible]] states that "What this practice was is unknown. Paul does not say if he of approved it or not: he uses it merely for an ''ad hominem'' argument".Jerusalem Bible (1966), note at 1 Corinthians 15:29 ===Be not deceived: 33–4=== Verse 33 has a quotation from classical Greek literature. According to the church historian [[Socrates of Constantinople]]''The Ecclesiastical History of Socrates ... '', London: George Bell, 1897. book III, chapter 16, verse 114, page 194. See also the introductory essay to [[Samson Agonistes]] by [[John Milton]], [http://www.dartmouth.edu/~milton/reading_room/samson/tragedy Of that sort of Dramatic Poem which is call'd Tragedy]. it is from a Greek tragedy of [[Euripides]], but modern scholarship, following [[Jerome]]''Commentarium ad Titum'' 100.1 attributes it to the comedy ''Thaĩs'' by [[Menander#Famous quotations|Menander]], or Menander quoting Euripides. It might not have been a direct quote by Paul: "This saying was widely known as a familiar quotation." {{cite book|author=Hans Conzelmann |title=1 Corinthians: A Commentary on the First Epistle to the Corinthians |others=James W. Leach (translator) |location=Philadelphia|publisher=Fortress Press|year=1975 |isbn=0800660056 |pages=278–279 fn 132}} {{quotation|33 Be not deceived: evil communications corrupt good manners.
34 Awake to righteousness, and sin not; for some have not the knowledge of God: I speak this to your shame.}} ===Resurrection of the body: 35–58=== [[File:B Facundus 167.jpg|thumb|'''The Last Trump''', illumination by Facundus, 1047. Madrid, [[Biblioteca Nacional de España]].]] The chapter concludes with an account of the nature of the resurrection. At the [[Last Judgement]] the dead will be raised and both the living and the dead transformed into "spiritual bodies" (44):E.P. Sanders (1991) ''Paul''. Oxford University Press: 29–30 ({{ISBN|0192876791}}). For a [[homiletics|homiletic]] application, see [[Charles Davis Tillman#References|"When I Get to the End of the Way" (References)]]. {{quotation|51 Behold, I shew you a mystery; We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed,
52 In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump: for the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed.
53 For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality.}} Through the power of Christ "Death is swallowed up in victory" (54). Referencing a verse in [[Hosea]], Paul asks: "O death where is thy sting? O grave where is thy victory?" (55), equating sin with death and the [[Torah|Judaic Law]] which have now been conquered and superseded by the victory of Christ. ==Catechism of the Catholic Church== {{main|Catechism of the Catholic Church}} {{quote|FATHER, . . . this is eternal life, that they may know you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom you have sent. 1 God our Savior desires all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth. 2 There is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved 3 than the name of JESUS.{{cite web|title=Prologue|url=http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/prologue.htm|website=Catechism of the Catholic Church|publisher=Vatican|accessdate=2014-08-14}}}} ==Early Christian creed== {{main|List of Christian creeds}} Verses 3–5 (plus possible additional verses) may be one of the earliest [[creed]]s about Jesus' death and resurrection. The antiquity of the creed has been noted by most biblical scholars, probably originating from the [[Early centers of Christianity#Jerusalem|Jerusalem apostolic community]].see Wolfhart Pannenberg, Jesus – God and Man translated Lewis Wilkins and Duane Pribe (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1968) p. 90; Oscar Cullmann, The Early church: Studies in Early Christian History and Theology, ed. A. J. B. Higgins (Philadelphia: Westminster, 1966) p. 66; R. E. Brown, The Virginal Conception and Bodily Resurrection of Jesus (New York: Paulist Press, 1973) p. 81; Thomas Sheehan, First Coming: How the Kingdom of God Became Christianity (New York: Random House, 1986) pp. 110, 118; Ulrich Wilckens, Resurrection translated A. M. Stewart (Edinburgh: Saint Andrew, 1977) p. 2; Hans Grass, Ostergeschen und Osterberichte, Second Edition (Gottingen: Vandenhoeck und Ruprecht, 1962) p. 96; Grass favors the origin in Damascus.{{quote|For I delivered to you as of first importance what I also received, that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures, and that He was buried, and that He was raised on the third day according to the Scriptures, and that He appeared to Peter, then to the twelve...}} ==See also== * ''[[Commentary on the Apocalypse]]'' * [[Resurrection of Jesus]] * Related [[Bible]] parts: [[Genesis creation narrative|Genesis 2]], [[Romans 5]], [[Romans 6]], [[Galatians 1]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1%20corinthians%2015;&version=9; 1 Corinthians: 15] * [http://www.bible.org/page.php?page_id=810 A Refresher Course on the Resurrection of the Dead] {{First Epistle to the Corinthians}} [[Category:1 Corinthians 15| ]] [[Category:Afterlife in Christianity]] [[Category:First Epistle to the Corinthians chapters|15]] [[Category:Resurrection of Jesus in the New Testament]]

{{Infobox saint | name = [[Saint]]
Abakuh | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | titles =Martyr | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place =[[Al Fayyum]], [[Egypt]] | feast_day = 23 January | venerated_in = [[Roman Catholic Church]],
[[Eastern Orthodox Church]],
[[Oriental Orthodox Church]] | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = | attributes = | patronage = | issues = | suppressed_date = | suppressed_by = | influences = | tradition = | influenced = | major_works = }} '''Abakuh''' (also known as '''Apa Kauh''') was a [[martyr]] of Bamujeh in the [[Al Fayyum]] area of [[Egypt]]. He was a zealous Christian who was martyred for his Christianity with eight companions. His [[feast day]] is January 23. He is referenced in the ''[[Synaxaire Arabe-Jacobite]]''. ==References== *Holweck, F. G. ''A Biographical Dictionary of the Saints''. St. Louis, MO: B. Herder Book Co. 1924. {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abakuh}} [[Category:Christian saints in unknown century]] [[Category:Christian martyrs]] [[Category:Egyptian Christian saints]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] {{Egypt-bio-stub}} {{Saint-stub}}

{{Infobox yoga school |name=Agni Yoga |color= |bgcolor= |religious_origins= |regional_origins= |founding_gurus=[[Helena Roerich]] and [[Nicholas Roerich]] |popularity=Growing from the 20th century |derivatives= |related_schools=[[Theosophy (Blavatskian)]] |practice_emphases=''Conscious striving in one's daily life'' |other_topics= }} [[Image:Pax cultura.svg |right||thumb|Roerichs [[Banner of Peace]] as the symbol of protection of Culture.{{cite web |url=http://en.icr.su/museum/layout/banner/03.php |title=The Banner of Peace became famous on the planet as the symbol of protection of Culture |publisher=International Centre of the Roerichs |accessdate=21 November 2018 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/746JYBPJ4 |archivedate=21 November 2018}}]] '''Agni Yoga''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Агни Йога'') or the '''Living Ethics''' (Russian: ''Жива́я Этика''), or the '''Teaching of Life''' (Russian: ''Учение Жизни'') is a one of the [[Neo-Theosophy|neo-theosophical]] [[religious doctrine]] transmitted by the [[Helena Roerich]] and [[Nicholas Roerich]] from 1920. The term ''Agni Yoga'' means “Mergence with Divine Fire” or “Path to Mergence with Divine Fire”. This term was introduced by the Roerichs. The followers of Agni Yoga believe that the teaching was given to the Roerich family and their associates by [[Masters of the Ancient Wisdom|Master]] [[Morya (Theosophy)|Morya]], the [[guru]] of Roerichs and [[Helena Blavatsky]], one of the founders of the modern theosophical movement and the [[Theosophical Society]]. Agni Yoga is a path of practice in daily life. It is the [[yoga]] of fiery energy, of consciousness, of responsible, directed thought. It teaches that the evolution of the [[planetary consciousness]] is a pressing necessity and that, through [[Individual#Buddhism|individual]] striving, it is an attainable aspiration for mankind. According to Helena Roerich, Agni Yoga is the [[Thesis, antithesis, synthesis|synthesis]] of all [[yoga]]s. In all the [[List of Hindu texts|ancient Hindu scriptures]], the approaching Fiery Age was predicted. Agni-Fire, which to a varying degree is at the heart of all the yogas, will extremely sate the atmosphere of our planet, and all the branches of Yoga will be merged into a fiery synthesis. Agni Yoga is a fire [[baptism]]. The most significant features of Agni Yoga are cosmism and [[universalism]]. They are expressed in the interpretation of any phenomena of human existence from the point of view of their cosmic significance and interrelation with the being of the [[Universe]]. Agni Yoga played a significant role in bringing knowledge of [[Asian religions]] to [[Western world]]. Living Ethics has an international following and has thousands of adherents. The ideas of Teaching of Life have exerted an influence on another [[esoteric]] movements and philosophies, among them the [[New Age]] and [[Transhumanism]]. ==Birth of the new religion== {{double image |right|Helena Roerich (V. Serov).jpg |170 |HPB by Schmiechen.jpg |171 |Two women had a strong influence on the creation of the religious doctrine of Agni yoga, [[Helena Roerich]] by [[Valentin Serov|Serov]] (left) and [[Helena Blavatsky]] by [[:de:Hermann Schmiechen|Schmiechen]]}} ===Etymology and concept=== The term ''Agni Yoga'' means “Mergence with Divine Fire” or “Path to Mergence with Divine Fire”. This term was introduced to the western public by the [[Nicholas Roerich]] and [[Helena Roerich]].{{cite web |url=http://www.highest-yoga.info/en/yoga/agni-yoga.html |title=Agni Yoga |publisher=highest-yoga.info |accessdate=21 November 2018 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/746J1WitJ |archivedate=21 November 2018}} ''[[Agni]]'' ({{lang-sa|अग्नि}}) is the [[Vedas|Vedic]] and Living Ethics ''God of Fire'', one marks immortality and the symbol of life. Agni is one of the supreme gods in the [[Rigveda]]. In Agni Yoga it is the Creative Fire of the Universe, the root of the "Fire of Space"; and "psychic energy", the powers of the human mind and heart, particularly those manifesting in love, thought, and creativity.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/world-religions/oclc/659908115?ht=edition&referer=null |author=[[John Bowker (theologian)|Bowker, John]] |title=World Religions |publisher=New York: DK Publishing, Inc. |accessdate=10 September 2018 |year=1997 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6wJMDtNzh?url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/world-religions/oclc/659908115?ht=edition&referer=null |archivedate=8 January 2018 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} The origin myth found in many [[Indo-European culture]]s Agni is a bird like being, that brings fire from the gods to mankind. Alternatively, this messenger brings an elixir of immortality from heaven to [[Earth]]. In the early [[Vedic literature]], Agni primarily connotes the fire as a god, one reflecting the primordial powers to consume, transform and convey.{{cite book |author=Arthur Anthony Macdonell |title=Vedic Mythology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b7Meabtj8mcC |year=1898 |publisher=Motilal Banarsidass |isbn=978-81-208-1113-3 |pages=15–16, 92–93 |accessdate=27 October 2018}} ''[[Yoga]]'' ({{lang-sa|योग}}; {{pronunciation|Yoga pronunciation.ogg |help=no}}) is one of the six orthodox schools of [[Hindu philosophy]]. There is a broad variety of yoga schools, practices, and goals in [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], and [[Jainism]]. Yoga is a group of [[soul|spiritual]], [[mind|mental]], and [[Human body|physical]] practices or disciplines which originated in [[ancient India]]. The term ''Yoga'' has been applied to a variety of practices and methods. In Hinduism these include [[Jnana yoga|Jnana Yoga]], [[Bhakti yoga|Bhakti Yoga]], [[Karma yoga|Karma Yoga]], [[Laya yoga|Laya Yoga]] and [[Hatha yoga|Hatha Yoga]]. The term ''[[Rāja yoga]]'' originally referred to the ultimate goal of yoga, which is [[Samadhi]] ([[Sanskrit]]: {{lang|sa|समाधि}}, {{IPA-hns|səˈmaːdʱi|hi}}), but was popularised by [[Swami Vivekananda]] as the common name for ''Ashtanga Yoga''. In the Ashtanga Yoga tradition, ''Samadhi'' is the eighth and final limb identified in the [[Yoga Sutras of Patanjali]].{{cite book |author=[[Georg Feuerstein]] |title=The Yoga Tradition: Its History, Literature, Philosophy and Practice |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cI5XDwAAQBAJ |date=23 October 2012 |publisher=Hohm Press |isbn=978-1-935387-39-8 |page=37 |accessdate=10 September 2018}}{{cite book |url= http://www.universaltheosophy.com/pdf-library/Yoga%20Darshana%20Eng%20with%20Vyasa%20Bhashya%20&%20Notes%20-%20Ganganath%20Jha%201907.pdf |title=The Yoga-darsana: The sutras of Patanjali with the Bhasya of Vyasa - Book 3 GN Jha (Translator) |publisher=Harvard University Archives |pages=94-96 |accessdate=27 November 2018 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/74EpHxkeG |archivedate=27 November 2018}} {{Quote box |width = 25em |border = 3px |align = left |bgcolor = #D0F0C0 |fontsize = 99% |quote = Agni Yoga is a synthesis of all [[Yoga]]s. In all the ancient [[Hindu texts|Hindu scriptures]] the approaching Fiery Epoch has been predicted. It is said that [[Agni]]—the Fire that is found in varying degrees at the foundation of all Yogas will saturate the atmosphere of our planet tremendously, and all the branches of Yoga will be fused into a fiery synthesis. Verily, Agni Yoga is a fiery [[baptism]] |salign = left |source = —[[Helena Roerich]]{{cite book |url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Letters-of-Helena-Roerich-I.php |last=Roerich |first=Helena |year=1929-1935 |title=Letters of Helena Roerich |volume=1 |page=411 |publisher=agniyoga.org |accessdate=25 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6p2O3gT5L? |archivedate=17 March 2017}} }} ''[[Aum]]'' or ''Oṃ'' ([[Devanagari]]: {{script|Deva|'''ॐ'''}}), {{audio|Om pro.ogg|listen}}, is a sacred sound and a spiritual symbol in [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], and [[Jainism]]. This word has three [[phoneme]]s: ''a'', ''u'', and ''m'', though it is often described as [[trisyllabic]] despite this being either archaic or the result of translation.{{cite-book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e89eDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT287&dq=%22om%22+%22three%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWvpr3_8zcAhVDd6wKHehnCgIQ6AEIQzAF#v=onepage&q=%22om%22%20%22three%22&f=false |title=The Om Mala: Meanings of the Mystic Sound |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=9789387471856 |accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{cite-book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dLlIAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA61&dq=%22om%22+%22three%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWvpr3_8zcAhVDd6wKHehnCgIQ6AEITzAH#v=onepage&q=%22om%22%20%22three%22&f=false |author=Vālmīki |year=1891 |title=The Yoga-vásishtha-mahárámáyana of Válmiki |volume=1 |page=61 |publisher=Bonnerjee and Company |accessdate=26 September 2018}} That signifies the essence of the ultimate reality, consciousness or [[Atman (Hinduism)|Atman]].{{cite-book |url=https://www.amazon.com/Illustrated-Encyclopedia-Hinduism-Vol-N-Z/dp/0823931803/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1538043614&sr=1-1 |author=James G Lochtefeld |title=The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Hinduism |year=2002| volume=2 N-Z |page=482 |publisher=Rosen Publishing |isbn=978-0823931804 |accessdate=27 September 2018}} The twelfth book of the [[Scriptures]] of Agni Yoga is called ''AUM''. Aum, as this book says, was a synthesis of sonant strivings. Prayer and inward concentration are excellent attainments which render healthful the state of the spirit. Each one in his own way has contributed a manifestation useful to spiritual concentration, whether he sought the solution in music, in song, or in the dance; man was striving to create a particularly exalted state of mind, promoting the reception of the higher energies.{{cite web| url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Aum.php |title=Aum, §4 |publisher=agniyoga.org |year=1936 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73ASzqsWl?url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Aum.php |archivedate=14 October 2018}} ''Ur'' or ''[[Aditi]]'' ([[Sanskrit]]: अदिति "limitless"),From ''a-'' ([[privative a]]) and ''diti'' "bound," which is from the Proto Indo-European root *''da-'' "to bind." in the [[Vedas]] and Living Ethics is the Mother of the gods and all twelve zodiacal spirits from whose cosmic matrix the heavenly bodies were born. As celestial mother of every existing form and being, the synthesis of all things, she is associated with space and with mystic speech. She is mentioned nearly 80 times in the [[Rigveda]]: the verse "[[Daksha]] sprang from Aditi and Aditi from Daksha" is seen by Theosophists as a reference to "the eternal cyclic re-birth of the same divine Essence" and divine wisdom.{{cite web |url=http://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/etgloss/adi-ag.htm |title=Adi-Ag: Encyclopedic Theosophical Glossary |publisher=Theosociety.org |accessdate=4 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73fwLSZQ7?url=https://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/etgloss/adi-ag.htm |archivedate=4 November 2018}} "Ur is the root of the Light of Fire", it is stated in the [[holy writ]] of Agni Yoga.{{cite web |url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Fiery-World-I.php |title=Fiery World Part I Preface |publisher=agniyoga.org |accessdate=14 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73ATDKnlB?url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Fiery-World-I.php |archivedate=14 October 2018}} ''[[Shambhala]]'' ({{lang-sa|शम्भलः}}, {{bo|t=བདེ་འབྱུང}};) is a birthplace of [[Kalki]], the final incarnation of [[Vishnu]], who will usher in a New Age — [[Satya Yuga]]. Shambhala is ruled over by [[Maitreya]].{{cite web |url=https://docviewer.yandex.ru/view/94772562/?*=pJNhApHCEiN8vf%2FRWPuXaI3zG%%3D&page=1 |title=Maitreya |year=2006 |publisher=Agni Yoga Society |accessdate=23 September 2018}} The [[Kalacakra Tantra]] prophesies that when all is lost, Kalki will emerge from Shambhala to vanquish "Dark Forces" and usher in a worldwide [[Golden Age]]. Shambhala is also called [[Shangri-la]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oUIum8H_9qgC |last=LePage |first=Victoria| title=Shambhala: The Fascinating Truth Behind the Myth of Shangri-La |year=1996 |publisher=Quest Books |pages=125–126 |isbn=9780835607506 |accessdate=18 September 2018}} [[File:Moryaportrait.jpg |thumb |240 px |right |[[Morya (Theosophy)|Master Morya]] by [[:nl:Hermann Schmiechen|Hermann Schmiechen]], 1884.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=74jEiVAhVHEC&pg=PA142#v=onepage&q&f=false |author=Sarah Diane Sasson |title=Yearning for the New Age: Laura Holloway-Langford and Late Victorian Spirituality (Religion in North America) |publisher=[[Indiana University Press]] |year=2012 |pages=142—144 |isbn=9780253001771 |accessdate=27 September 2018}}
«Hermann Schmiechen was a German painter living in London who had joined the Theosophical Society. He agreed to take part in a ''psychical experiment'' to see if images could be transferred to his mind from those who had seen the Masters...»]] ''[[Morya (Theosophy)|Morya]]'' is one of the [[Masters of the Ancient Wisdom]] within modern Theosophical beliefs.{{cite book |last2=[[:cv:Ауновская Ольга Константиновна |Aunovsky]] |first2=O. K. |last1=[[Victor Skumin|Skumin]] |first1=V. A. |year=1995 |script-title=ru: Светоносцы (о семье Рерихов) |trans-title=The Bringers of the Light (The story of the Roerich family) |location=[[Novocheboksarsk]] |publisher=TEROS |url=http://biblmdkz.ru/svet.html |isbn=5-88167-004-3 |language=Russian |accessdate=10 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6t3vBmhIG? |archivedate=28 August 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} He is one of the [[Mahatmas]] who inspired the founding of the Theosophy and Agni Yoga.{{cite web |url=https://sirius-eng.net/liki/moria.htm |title=Master Morya |publisher=sirius-eng.net |accessdate=17 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6wJLsG9R7?|archivedate=8 January 2018}} He has written and dictated the letters with the goal of elevating mankind and bringing in a New Age.{{cite web |url=http://www.reversespins.com/agninewera.html |title=El Morya on Prophecy, the New Era and the Age of Maitreya |publisher=Reverse Spins |accessdate=4 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73fwqCfmS?url=http://www.reversespins.com/agninewera.html |archivedate=4 November 2018}} The Master Morya will physically incarnate in order to be the [[Manu (Theosophy)|Manu]] ("progenitor") of the new [[Root race#The sixth root race|root race]].{{cite book |last=Skumin |first=Victor |script-title=ru: Гимны Культуры Здоровья |trans-title=Gimns of Culture of Health |year=2007 |location=[[Cheboksary]] |publisher=To Health via Culture |url=http://biblmdkz.ru/gimn.html |language=Russian |isbn=978-5-88167-030-6 |accessdate=27 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6vmcoqT4R?url=http://biblmdkz.ru/gimn.html |archivedate=17 December 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}}[[Annie Besant|Besant]]/[[Charles Webster Leadbeater|Leadbeater]], [[Man: Whence, How and Whither, a Record of Clairvoyant Investigation|''Man: How, Whence, and Whither?'', p. 353-495]]. ''[[Tara (Buddhism)|Tara]] Urusvati'' (''The Light of the Morning Star'') is the spiritual name of [[Helena Roerich]] (1879 – 1955) in Agni Yoga and [[Rerikhism]].{{cite book |last=Skumin |first=V. A. |script-title=ru: Афоризмы Агни Йоги |trans-title=Sutras of Agni Yoga |year=1995 |location=Novocheboksarsk |publisher=Teros |url=http://biblmdkz.ru/af.html |language=Russian |isbn=5-88167-007-8 |accessdate=12 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6wIUCotb1?url=http://biblmdkz.ru/af.html |archivedate=7 January 2018 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} She was a teacher and healer as well as the inspired co-author of the ''Agni Yoga series'', the first English books about Living Ethics and the Roerichs' relationship with their Guru.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ru/books/about/Nicholas_and_Helena_Roerich.html?id=YltbBgAAQBAJ&redir_esc=y |last=Drayer |first=Ruth Abrams |year=2014 |title=Nicholas & Helena Roerich: The Spiritual Journey of Two Great Artists & Peacemakers |isbn=9780835631143 |publisher=Quest Books |origyear=2005 |page=309 |accessdate=10 September 2018}} Each of the 935 paragraphs of the book "Supermundane" begins with the word "Urusvati".{{cite web| url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Supermundane.php |title=Supermundane |publisher=agniyoga.org |year=1938 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73ATQDcyS?url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Supermundane.php |archivedate=14 October 2018}} In the epilogue of the book "Agni Yoga" she was called the Mother of Agni Yoga.{{cite web| url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Agni-Yoga.php |title=Agni yoga Epilogue |publisher=agniyoga.org |year=1929 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73ATcf7iT?url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Agni-Yoga.php |archivedate=14 October 2018}} ''Fuyama'' is the spiritual name of [[Nicholas Roerich]] (1874 – 1947) in Agni Yoga and Rerikhism. He was an internationally acclaimed artist, conservationist, archeologist, humanitarian and peacemaker.{{cite journal |url=http://biblmdkz.ru/j10_2.html |title=Фуяма — огненный Гуру-Покровитель духовного человечества |trans-title=Fuyama (N. Roerich's spiritual name) is a Fiery Guru-patron of spiritual humanity |author=Skumin VA |year=2004 |journal=To Health via Culture |volume=10 |pages=31–34 |issn=0204-3440 |accessdate=21 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6vmbpbde2?url=http://biblmdkz.ru/j10_2.html |archivedate=17 December 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} Nicolas Roerich called Urusvati “She Who Leads” in his creations.{{cite web |url=http://irmtkullu.com/the-roerich-family/helena-roerich/ |title=Helena Ivanovna Roerich (1879 – 1955) |publisher=irmtkullu.com |accessdate=4 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73fxVWJee?url=http://irmtkullu.com/the-roerich-family/helena-roerich/ |archivedate=4 November 2018}} ''[[Karma]]'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɑr|m|ə}}; {{lang-sa|कर्म|karma}}, {{IPA-sa|ˈkərmə|IPA|Karma.ogg}}) means action, work or deed. It also refers to the spiritual principle of cause and effect where intent and actions of an individual influence his future. Good intent and good deeds contribute to good karma and future happiness, while bad intent and bad deeds contribute to bad karma and future suffering. With origins in [[History of India|ancient India]]'s [[Vedic civilization]], the philosophy of karma is closely associated with the idea of [[Reincarnation|rebirth]] in many schools of [[Indian religions]], particularly [[Karma in Hinduism|Hinduism]], [[Karma in Buddhism|Buddhism]], [[Karma in Jainism|Jainism]] and [[Sikhism]].{{cite book |author=Parvesh Singla |title=The Manual of Life – Karma |year=2002 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1mXR35jX-TsC&pg=PP5 |publisher=books.google.com |pages=5–7 |accessdate=17 October 2018}} Karma works as one of the great principles of Cosmic Action. ''When man realizes the power of karma and strives to express the best aspirations, his path is parallel with the universal energy. The universal energy attracts the creative strivings. The future and the Infinite are thus being built'', written in the Holy Scripture of Agni Yoga.{{cite book |url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Infinity-II.php |title=Infinity Part II, 159 |publisher=agniyoga.org |year=1930 |accessdate=21 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73L93b1d9?url=http://agniyoga.org/ay_en/Infinity-II.php |archivedate=21 October 2018}} ''[[Spiritual evolution]]'' is the [[philosophy|philosophical]], [[theology|theological]], [[Esoteric knowledge|esoteric]] or [[Spirituality|spiritual]] idea that nature and human beings and [[human culture]] evolve: either extending from an established [[esoteric cosmology|cosmological]] [[pattern]] (ascent), or in accordance with certain pre-established potentials.{{YouTube |GbWMw249xY8 |The Hidden History of Humanity}} The phrase "spiritual evolution" can occur in the context of ''higher evolution'', a term used to differentiate psychological, mental, or spiritual evolution from the ''lower evolution'' or [[biological evolution]] of physical form. {{cite book | last1 = Piyasīlo | first1 = | author-link1 = Piya Tan | title = The Buddha's teachings: a study of comparative Buddhism in truth, tradition & transformation | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=dKMEAQAAIAAJ | series = Dharmafarer integrated syllabus series | issue = 4 | edition = 2 | publisher = Dharmafarer Enterprises | publication-date = 1991 | page = 130 | isbn = 9789839030013 | accessdate = 27 September 2018 | quote = The instrument of this growth is the Dharma which is the path of the Higher Evolution. The term 'Higher' here refers to the mind - the basis of spiritual evolution. In contrast to the Higher Evolution, the biological (or Darwinian) evolution is known as the Lower Evolution. }} The concept of spiritual evolution is also complemented by the idea of a [[creative impulse]] in human beings, known as [[Epigenesis (biology)|epigenesis]]. {{cite book | last1 = Heindel | first1 = Max | author-link1 = Max Heindel | title = The Rosicrucian Philosophy in Questions and Answers | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ozFDAAAAIAAJ | publisher = Rosicrucian Fellowship | publication-date = 1922 | edition = 3 | page = 10 | accessdate = 27 September 2018 | quote = Since the mind was given to man, it is this original creative impulse, epigenesis, which has been the cause of all our development[...] }} ''Agni Yoga'', in general, is a neo-theosophical religious doctrine{{cite web |url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=EZYsPQgBNioC&pg=PA103#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Claiming Knowledge: Strategies of Epistemology from Theosophy to the New Age |publisher=books.google.ru |isbn=9789004136380 |accessdate=14 September 2018}} transmitted by the Helena and Nicholas Roerichs from 1920. The followers of ''Living Ethics'' believe that the teaching was given to the Roerichs' family{{cite web |url=http://en.icr.su/family/ |title=Roerichs' family |publisher=International Centre of the Roerichs |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hG4fIF5?url=http://en.icr.su/family/ |archivedate=5 November 2018}} and their associates by Master Morya, the guru of Roerichs and Helena Blavatsky, one of the founders of the modern theosophical movement and the Theosophical Society.{{cite web |url=http://www.katinkahesselink.net/path6.htm |title=The Esoteric Studies Guide |publisher=katinkahesselink.net |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hGKLp2d?url=http://www.katinkahesselink.net/path6.htm |archivedate=5 November 2018}} ''Teaching of Life'' is a path of practice in daily life. It is the yoga of fiery energy, of consciousness, of responsible, directed thought. It teaches that the evolution of the [[planetary consciousness]] is a pressing necessity and that, through individual striving, it is an attainable aspiration for mankind.{{cite web |url=http://www.agniyoga.org/ay_info.html |title=About Agni Yoga |publisher=agniyoga.org |accessdate=8 September 2018 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/65YcI6cTu?url=http://www.agniyoga.org/ay_info.html |archive-date=19 February 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}} The most significant features of Agni Yoga are cosmism and universalism. They are expressed in the interpretation of any phenomena of human existence from the point of view of their cosmic significance and interrelation with the being of the Universe.{{cite book |last=Samokhina |first=N. E. |script-title=ru: Проблема человека в Агни-Йоге. Автореф. дисс. на соиск. уч. ст. канд. философ. наук |trans-title=The problem of man in Agni Yoga. Thesis for the degree of candidate of philosophical sciences |url=http://cheloveknauka.com/v/401041/a#?page=3 |year=1994 |pages=3-4 |language=Russian |publisher=[[Moscow State University]] |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hH1oQtD?url=http://cheloveknauka.com/problema-cheloveka-v-agni-yoge |archivedate=5 November 2018}} ===Precursors of Agni Yoga=== [[File:Leo Tolstoy The Voice of the Silence.jpg |240 px |thumb |''[[The Voice of the Silence]]'' presented by Helena Blavatsky to [[Leo Tolstoy]] ([[Yasnaya Polyana]], a [[writer's home]]).]] ====Theosophy==== {{Main|Theosophy (Blavatskian)}} The [[Theosophical Society]] was officially formed in [[New York City]] on 17 November 1875 by [[Helena Blavatsky]], [[Henry Steel Olcott]], [[William Quan Judge]], and others. It was self-described as "an unsectarian body of seekers after Truth, who endeavour to promote Brotherhood and strive to serve humanity." After a few years Olcott and Blavatsky moved to India and established the International Headquarters at [[Theosophical Society Adyar|Adyar]], in [[Chennai|Madras]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.de/books/about/The_Theosophical_Movement.html?id=OC4IAQAAIAAJ&redir_esc=y |year=1951 |title=The Theosophical Movement 1875–1950 |publisher=Cunningham Press |location=Los Angeles |accessdate=26 September 2018}} Madame Blavatsky (''Upasica'' - this spiritual name means a female lay disciple. So the ''Teachers'' called [[Helena Petrovna Blavatsky|HPB]]{{cite book| title=Theosophy and culture: Nicholas Roerich |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=AdpG8sGt8K8C&printsec=frontcover&hl=ru&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |author=Stasulane, Anita |publisher=Gregorian Biblical BookShop |location=Rome |volume=8 |year=2005 |page=26-27 |isbn=978-88-7839-035-5 |accessdate=16 October 2018}}), the greatest [[occultist]] in the history of [[Western civilization]], insisted that [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]] is not a [[religion]], although did refer to it as the modern transmission of the "once universal religion" that she claimed had existed deep into the human past. The motto of the Theosophical movement: '''There is no Religion higher than Truth'''.{{cite journal |url=http://www.ultindia.org/tm_magazine/TMOct2018.pdf |title=The motto is located at the top of the magazine page |journal=The Theosophical Movement. A Magazine Devoted to The Living of the Higher Life |year=2018 |volume=10 |issue=6 |publisher=Theosopy Company ([[India]], [[Mumbai]]) Private LTD |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qpmiLML?url=http://www.ultindia.org/tm_magazine/TMOct2018.pdf |archivedate=11 November 2018}} Theosophical organisations, regard it as a system that embraces what they see as the "essential truth" underlying religion, philosophy, and science. Theosophical groups allow their members to hold other religious allegiances, resulting in [[Theosophists]] who also identify as [[Christians]], [[Buddhists]], or [[Hindus]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ru/books/about/Is_Theosophy_a_Religion.html?id=2Kd5ngEACAAJ&source=kp_cover&redir_esc=y |last=Blavatsky |first=Helena |year=2013 |title=Is Theosophy a Religion? |pages=24 |isbn=9781258977719 |accessdate=10 September 2018}} The term [[Neo-Theosophy]] was coined by Ferdinand T. Brooks around 1912. This term used by the followers of Helena Blavatsky to denominate the system of theosophical ideas expounded following the death of Blavatsky in 1891. This material differed in major respects from Blavatsky's original presentation, but it is accepted as genuinely theosophical by many theosophists around the world.{{cite book |url=http://www.blavatskyarchives.com/thomas/ |title=Theosophy Versus Neo-Theosophy: Margaret Thomas' Study of C. W. Leadbeater's and Annie Besant's Theosophical Teachings |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jORxNRh?url=http://www.blavatskyarchives.com/thomas/ |archivedate=6 November 2018}} Daryl S. Paulson associates "Neo-Theosophy" with [[Alice Bailey]].{{cite journal |url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc799372/ |first=Daryl S. |last=Paulson |title=The Near-Death Experience: An Integration of Cultural, Spiritual, and Physical Perspectives |journal=Journal of Near-Death Studies |publisher=New York, N.Y.: Human Sciences Press |volume=18 |number=1 |year=1999 |pages=13-25 |issn=0891-4494 |oclc=14781775 |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hsZ4WWX?url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc799372/ |archivedate=5 November 2018}} She introduced the term [[New Age]] – [[Age of Aquarius]].{{cite book |url=https://www.gettextbooks.co.uk/isbn/9780853301059/ |last=Bailey |first=Alice A. |year=2012 |title=Education in the New Age |pages=174 |publisher=gettextbooks.co.uk |isbn=978-0853301059 |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hrBsq4y?url=https://www.gettextbooks.co.uk/isbn/9780853301059/ |archivedate=5 November 2018}} Other neo-theosophists include [[Rudolf Steiner]]'s contemporary [[Peter Deunov]] and [[Samael Aun Weor]]. [[Dion Fortune]] and [[Aleister Crowley]] were also influencers of the leading edge of the theosophical movement. Some examples of neo-theosophists today include [[Benjamin Creme]]{{cite book| url=http://share-international.org/books/PDFs/BCreme_TransmissionAMeditationForTheNewAge_Jun06.pdf |author=[[Benjamin Creme]] |title=Transmission A meditation for the New Age |publisher=share-international.org |accessdate=5 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73hqv2NN3?url=http://share-international.org/books/PDFs/BCreme_TransmissionAMeditationForTheNewAge_Jun06.pdf |archivedate=5 November 2018}} and [[Victor Skumin]]. So, in 1990, Skumin, based on the theosophical concept of [[spiritual evolution]], proposed a classification of '''Homo spiritalis''' ([[Latin]]: ''Spiritual man''), the sixth root race, consisting of eight sub-races (subspecies): ''HS-0'' Anabiosis spiritalis, ''HS-1'' Scientella spiritalis, ''HS-2'' Aurora spiritalis, ''HS-3'' Ascensus spiritalis, ''HS-4'' Vocatus spiritalis, ''HS-5'' Illuminatio spiritalis, ''НS-6'' Creatio spiritalis, and ''HS-7'' Servitus spiritalis.{{cite book |last=Skumin |first=V. A. |script-title=ru:Человек духовный: роль культуры духовного здоровья в утверждении новой человеческой расы на планете |trans-title=Spiritual man: The role of the Culture of spiritual health for approval of the new human race on the planet |year=1996 |publisher=theeuropeanlibrary.org |url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/record/3000010564370?query=%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80+%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD+ |language=Russian |isbn=5-88167-012-4 |accessdate=27 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hDz04YV5?url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/record/3000010564370?query=%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80+%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD+ |archivedate=3 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} ====Russian philosophy and Russian Cosmism ==== {{Main|List of Russian philosophers|Russian Cosmism}} [[File:Vladimir Solovyov 1892 by Nikolay Yarochenko.jpg |180 px |thumb |left |[[Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)|Vladimir Solovyov]] by [[Nikolai Yaroshenko]], 1892]] [[File:Pasternak fedorov.jpg |180 px |thumb |left |[[Nikolai Fyodorovich Fyodorov|Nikolai Fyodorov]] by [[Leonid Pasternak]]]] Russian [[philosophy]] as a separate entity started its development in the [[History of Russia (1892–1917)|19th century]], defined initially by the opposition of [[Westernizers]], advocating Russia's following the Western political and economical models, and [[Slavophiles]], insisting on developing [[Russia]] as a unique civilization. The latter group included [[Nikolai Danilevsky]] and [[Konstantin Leontiev]], the early founders of [[eurasianism]]. ''Slavophilia'' was an intellectual movement originating from 19th century that wanted the [[Russian Empire]] to be developed upon values and institutions derived from its early history. There were also similar movements in [[Bulgaria]], [[Croatia]], [[Czechoslovakia]], [[Poland]], and [[Serbia]]. Depending on the historical context, its opposite could be termed [[Slavophobia]], a fear of [[Slavic culture]].{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9068172/Slavophile |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica |title=Slavophile Russian history |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jPhqyh2?url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavophile |archivedate=6 November 2018}} The discussion of Russia's place in the world has since become the most characteristic feature of Russian philosophy. Notable philosophers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries include [[Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)|Vladimir Solovyev]], [[Vasily Rozanov]], [[Lev Shestov]], [[Leo Tolstoy]], [[Sergei Bulgakov]], [[Pavel Florensky]], [[Pitirim Sorokin]].In its further development, Russian philosophy was also marked by deep connection to [[literature]] and interest in [[creativity]], [[society]], [[religion]], and [[Russian cosmism]].{{cite-book |url=https://www.amazon.com/Red-Cosmos-Tsiolkovskii-Grandfather-Centennial/dp/1603441174 |author=James T. Andrews |title=Red cosmos: K.E. Tsiolkovskii, grandfather of Soviet rocketry (Centennial of Flight Series) |year=2009 |pp=168 |publisher=Texas A & M University Press |oclc=680622488 |isbn=9781603443609 |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jQDK95Y?url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/red-cosmos-ke-tsiolkovskii-grandfather-of-soviet-rocketry/oclc/680622488 |archivedate=6 November 2018}} Vladimir Solovyov described his encounters with the entity ''Sophia'' in his works, such as ''Three Encounters'' and ''Lectures on Godmanhood''. His fusion was driven by the desire to reconcile or unite with Orthodox Christianity the various traditions by the Russian [[Slavophiles]]' concept of [[sobornost]]. His Russian religious philosophy had a very strong impact on the [[Russian Symbolism|Russian Symbolist]] art movements of his time. His teachings on ''Sophia'', conceived as the merciful unifying feminine wisdom of God comparable to the Hebrew [[Shekinah]] or various goddess traditions, have been deemed a [[heresy]] by [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]] and as unsound and unorthodox by the [[Patriarchate of Moscow]].{{cite web |url=http://ecumenizm.tripod.com/ECUMENIZM/id17.html |title=The Sophian heresy and attempts to feminize God |publisher=ecumenizm.tripod.com |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jQWHmoo?url=http://ecumenizm.tripod.com/ECUMENIZM/id17.html |archivedate=6 November 2018}} [[File:Volition-of-the-Cosmos.jpg |180 px |right |thumb |The cover of the book "The Will of the Universe; Unknown Intelligent Forces" by [[Konstantin Tsiolkovsky|Tsiolkovsky]], 1928]] [[Nikolai Fyodorovich Fyodorov|Nikolai Fyodorov]] was a [[Russian Orthodox Christian]] philosopher, who was part of the Russian cosmism movement and a precursor of [[transhumanism]]. Fedorov argued that humanity is the culmination of [[evolution]], as well as its creator and director. Humans must therefore direct evolution where their reason and morality dictate. Fedorov stated that the struggle against death can become the most natural cause uniting all people, regardless of their nationality, race, citizenship or wealth. He called this the ''Common Cause''. Fedorov thought that death and afterdeath existence should become the subject of comprehensive scientific inquiry, that achieving [[immortality]] and revival is the greatest goal of science.{{cite web |url=http://www.berdyaev.com/berdiaev/berd_lib/1915_186.html |author=[[Nikolai Berdyaev]] |title=The religion of resuscitative resurrection The "Philosophy of the Common Task" of N. F. Fedorov |publisher=berdyaev.com |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jQibnOC?url=http://www.berdyaev.com/berdiaev/berd_lib/1915_186.html |archivedate=6 November 2018}} At the beginning of the 20th century, there was a burst of scientific investigation into interplanetary travel, largely driven by the fiction writers such as [[Jules Verne]] and [[Herbert Wells]] as well as philosophical movements like [[Russian cosmism]]. In 1903, [[Konstantin Tsiolkovsky]] published the first serious scientific work on space travel. His work was essentially unknown outside the [[Russian Empire]], but inside the country it inspired further research, experimentation and the formation of the Society for Studies of [[Interplanetary spaceflight]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k8CxJeFzCdQC&pg=PA26 |author=A. Bowdoin Van Riper |title=Rockets and Missiles: The Life Story of a Technology |date=29 October 2007 |publisher=[[JHU Press]] |isbn=978-0-8018-8792-5 |pages=26–28 |accessdate=13 October 2018}} Tsiolkovsky wrote a book called "The Will of the Universe; Unknown Intelligent Forces" in which he propounded a philosophy of [[panpsychism]]. He believed humans would eventually colonize the [[Milky Way]]. His thought preceded the Space Age by several decades, and some of what he foresaw in his imagination has come into being since his death. Tsiolkovsky did not believe in traditional religious cosmology, but instead he believed in a cosmic being that governed humans.{{cite book |url=https://www.prlib.ru/en/node/404538 |last=[[Konstantin Tsiolkovsky|Tsiolkovsky]] |first=Konstantin Eduardovich |title=The Will of the Universe; Unknown Intelligent Forces |place=[[Kaluga]] |publisher=The author's edition |year=1928 |pages=23 |language=Russian |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jR4GDrr?url=https://www.prlib.ru/en/node/404538 |archivedate=6 November 2018}} The ideas of the Russian philosophers and cossmists later were developed by those in the transhumanist movement and [[Rerikhism]].{{cite book |year=2013 |url=http://sovieteramuseum.com/?product=art-works-by-russian-cosmism-painter-xx-xxi-ct-catalogue-of-exhibition-2013 |title=Art works by Russian cosmism painter XX – XXI ct. Catalogue of exhibition 2013 |publisher=Roerich museum |accessdate=28 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qGPQz1bk? |archivedate=6 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://en.icr.su/work/conferencies/2003/index.php |title=International Scientific and Public Conference ”Cosmic World Outlook – New Mentality of the ХХI Century” |publisher=en.icr.su |accessdate=16 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ivdI4YXn?url=http://en.icr.su/work/conferencies/2003/index.php |archivedate=11 July 2016}} For example, the [[List of Russian scientists#Physicians and psychologists|Russian scientist]] [[Victor Skumin]] argues that the [[Victor Skumin#Culture of Health and other contributions|Culture of Health]] will play an important role in the creation of a human spiritual society into the [[Solar System]].{{cite book |last=[[Victor Skumin|Skumin]] |first=V. A. |script-title=ru: Культура здоровья — фундаментальная наука о человеке |trans-title=A Culture of Health as a fundamental human science |year=1995 |url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/record/3000010561594?query=%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80+%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD+ |language=Russian |isbn=5-88167-003-5 |accessdate=6 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73jRm9yyS?url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/record/3000010561594?query=виктор+скумин+ |archivedate=6 November 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://900igr.net/prezentatsii/fizkultura/Kultura-zdorovja/007-Kultura-zdorovja-fundamentalnaja-nauka-o-Dukhovnom-CHelovechestve.html |year=2009 |author=Kovaleva E. A. |title=Педагогический совет. Культура здоровья учащихся как фактор здоровьесберегающей среды школы. Слайд 7 |trans-title=Pedagogical Council. Slide 7 of the presentation "culture of health" to the lessons of physical education on the theme the "Health" |publisher=900igr.net |accessdate=28 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6wH2YJ5wh? |archivedate=6 January 2018}} ==Historical development== [[File:Roerich memorial and house (17293917288).jpg |thumb |180 px |right |140th birth anniversary of [[Nicholas Roerich]].{{cite web |url=https://www.rbth.com/arts/2014/10/12/nicholas_roerichs_140th_birth_anniversary_celebrated_in_kullu_valley_38961 |title=Nicholas Roerich’s 140th birth anniversary celebrated in Kullu Valley |publisher=The Voice of Russia |date=12 October 2014 |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qrR7wJl?url=https://www.rbth.com/arts/2014/10/12/nicholas_roerichs_140th_birth_anniversary_celebrated_in_kullu_valley_38961 |archivedate=11 November 2018}} ]] [[File:Roerich-Museum-1929.jpg |thumb |upright |[[Master Building]] in [[NYC]], 1929 view.]] Information about [[Vedanta]] and [[Buddhism]] spread in [[Western countries]] in the first decade of the 20th century. In the United States of the 1920s, when the voises in religion were arguing over [[fundamentalism]] and [[modernism]] as the only available choice, and long before [[Shangri-La]] had become a popularly accepted myth, a vanguard movement was promoting the alternative of the wisdom of the [[Eastern world]].{{cite journal |author=Brian Taves |year=1985 |title=Philosophy Into Popular Fiction: Talbot Mundy and The Theosophical Society |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/41171147?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents |journal=Southern California QuarterlyTo |volume=67 |issue=2 |pages=153-186 |doi=10.2307/41171147 |issn= |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qsRpCDp?url=http://scq.ucpress.edu/content/67/2/153 |archivedate=11 November 2018}} [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]] proposed the existence of a society of Secret Chiefs called the [[Great White Brotherhood]]. The members of this Brotherhood, in belief systems akin to Theosophy and [[New Age]], are said to be perfected beings of great power who spread spiritual teachings through selected humans. The members of the Brotherhood may be known as the [[Masters of the Ancient Wisdom]] or the [[Ascended Masters]]. They are referred to by [[theosophist]]s as Elder Brothers of the human race, [[Adept]]s, [[Mahātmā]]s, or simply as the Masters. The first person to talk about them in the West was [[Helena Blavatsky]], after she and other people claimed to have received messages from them. These included [[Nicholas Roerich]] and [[Helena Roerich]], too.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=TI6fAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+myth+of+the+Masters+revived&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY0bbboKTeAhWOhqYKHY0ABHMQ6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=The%20myth%20of%20the%20Masters%20revived&f=false |title=The myth of the Masters revived: The Occult Lives of Nikolai and Elena Roerich |publisher=books.google.ru |isbn=978-90-04-27043-5 |accessdate=26 October 2018}} She emphasized that knowledge was the leading path of all great Teachers. Knowledge will permit a free and vital approach to the great Teaching, as vitally real as is great Matter itself.{{cite book |url=https://www.smashwords.com/books/view/702099 |author=Helena Roerich |title=Foundations of Buddhism |publisher=Agni Yoga Society |year=2017 |isbn=9781946742353 |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qt2a8kH?url=https://www.smashwords.com/books/view/702099 |archivedate=11 November 2018}} When Nicholas Roerich passed away, his wife is believed to have carried on the work prescribed by Master Morya, “I exist only due to the ray of the Great Master, who said it was necessary for me to remain because no one could replace me as I worked under the highest Cosmic Sign, and this century was in need of my attainment”. The main aim of Helena Roerich was to spread the message of Agni Yoga.{{cite web |url=https://www.rbth.com/blogs/tatar_straits/2017/03/18/when-helena-roerich-called-kalimpong-home_721753 |title=When Helena Roerich called Kalimpong home |author=Ajay Kamalakaran |publisher=Russia beyond |date=18 March 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qtOgEyJ?url=https://www.rbth.com/blogs/tatar_straits/2017/03/18/when-helena-roerich-called-kalimpong-home_721753 |archivedate=11 November 2018}} ===The Agni Yoga Society in the State of New York=== The Agni Yoga Society was founded in 1920 by Helena and Nicholas Roerich. It is a non-profit educational institution incor|porated in 1946 under the laws of the [[State of New York]], and is supported entirely by voluntary contributions and membership dues. The organization was located in the building ''[[Master Apartments]]''. The aims of the Society are embodied in the philosophy that gives it its name—Agni Yoga—as contained in the books of the Agni Yoga Series published by the Society. In them is found a synthesis of ancient Eastern beliefs and modern Western thought and a bridge between the spiritual and the scientific.{{cite web| url=http://www.agniyoga.us/ |title=AGNI YOGA (Sacred Heart Fire) AGNI YOGA The Great Synthesis |publisher=agniyoga.us |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qtsQePo?url=http://www.agniyoga.us/ |archivedate=11 November 2018}} Unlike previous [[yoga]]s, Agni Yoga is a path of practice in daily life. It is the yoga of fiery energy, of consciousness, of responsible, directed thought. It teaches that the evolution of the planetary consciousness is a pressing necessity and that, through individual striving, it is an attainable aspiration for mankind. Though not systematized in an ordinary sense, it is a teaching that helps the student to discover moral and spiritual guide-posts by which to learn to govern his or her life and thus contribute to the [[common good]]. For this reason Agni Yoga has been called a ''Living ethic''. Speaking about the role of [[personality]] in the [[spiritual evolution]] of mankind, [[Helena Roerich]] wrote,{{cite web| url=http://www.aquaac.org/un/elttrs/201003.html |title=The Spiritual Work of the United Nations and the Liberation of Humanity Creating Fundamental Global Transformations through the Power of Thought |publisher=aquaac.org |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/73qu54znq?url=http://www.aquaac.org/un/elttrs/201003.html |archivedate=11 November 2018}}{{cite web| url=http://www.agniyoga.org/ay_en/Letters-of-Helena-Roerich-II.php |title=Letters of Helena Roerich II, 25 October 1936 |publisher=agniyoga.org |accessdate=25 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6p2OJSzbs?url=http://www.agniyoga.org/ay_en/Letters-of-Helena-Roerich-II.php |archivedate=17 March 2017}} {{quote|'' The greatest benefit that we can contribute consists in the broadening of consciousness, and the improvement and enrichment of our thinking, together with the purification of the heart, in order to strengthen our emanations; and by thus raising our vibrations, we restore the health of all that surrounds us. True, it is impossible to increase our store of psychic energy without the help of the Teacher; however if our hearts are open and purified, and if our organism permits it, the Teacher will not tarry in manifesting himself''.}} ===Latvian Roerich Society in Riga=== The [[Latvia]]n Roerich Society is one of the oldest society established by the Roerichs family.
