revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag=[[File:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|RN Ensign]] |Ship name=HMT ''Bedfordshire'' |Ship namesake=[[Bedfordshire]], England |Ship builder=Smith's Dock Co. |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=17 July 1935 |Ship completed=August 1935 |Ship acquired=August 1939 |Ship struck= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Sunk by {{GS|U-558||2}} on 11 May 1942 |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship tonnage=443 [[gross register tonnage|GRT]] |Ship length={{convert|162.3|ft}} |Ship beam={{convert|26.7|ft}} |Ship draught= |Ship propulsion=3-cylinder [[triple expansion engine]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship complement= |Ship sensors=[[ASDIC]] |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*1 × 4 inch gun; *1 × machine gun; *depth charges |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox NRHP |embed=yes |name = <center>HMT ''Bedfordshire'' (shipwreck and remains)</center> |image = |caption = |map_caption = |location = |nearest_city = [[Beaufort, North Carolina]] | locmapin = |built = |architect = |architecture = | added = 31 July 2015 | area = | refnum = 15000421 |mpsub= World War II Shipwrecks along the East Coast and Gulf of Mexico MPS |governing_body = }} |}
'''HMT<ref>HMT (His Majesty's Trawler) is a variation on the more commonly used British ship prefix HMS (His Majesty's Ship).</ref> ''Bedfordshire'' (FY141)''' was an armed [[naval trawler]] in the service of the [[Royal Naval Patrol Service]] during [[World War II]]. Transferred to the East Coast of the United States to assist the [[United States Navy]] with [[anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] patrols, she was staffed by a British and Canadian crew. ''Bedfordshire'' was sunk by the {{GS|U-558}} on 11 May 1942 off the coast of [[Ocracoke Island]] in the [[Outer Banks]] of [[North Carolina]], with the loss of all hands.
==Construction== ''Bedfordshire'' was built as a commercial [[trawling|fishing trawler]] by [[Smiths Dock Company]] of [[South Bank, Middlesbrough|South Bank]], [[Middlesbrough]], England. Launched at [[Teesside]] on 17 July 1935, she was completed in August 1935 and turned over to her owners, Bedfordshire Fishing Company of [[Grimsby]], managed by H. Markham Cook Ltd. ''Bedfordshire'' was {{convert|162.3|ft}} long, with a {{convert|26.7|ft|adj=on}} beam.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bedfordshire|series=Smiths Dock Company Yard List for vessels completed between 1930 and 1944|url=http://www.teesbuiltships.co.uk/smiths/19301944/bedfordshire1935.htm|publisher=teesbuiltships.co.uk|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref>
The [[Admiralty]] acquired ''Bedfordshire'' for anti-submarine duty in August 1939.<ref name=uboat.net>{{cite web |title=HMS Bedfordshire (FY 141) |url=http://uboat.net/allies/merchants/ships/1626.html |last=Helgason |first=Guðmundur |website=German U-boats of WWII - uboat.net |accessdate=25 Oct 2012 }}</ref> Converted for service as a naval trawler, she was armed with a 4-inch gun, machine guns, and [[depth charge]]s.
==Service in British waters== Following completion of her conversion in December 1940, HMT ''Bedfordshire'' undertook anti-submarine patrols and escort duty off the southwest coast of England and in the [[Bristol Channel]]. She served in this capacity throughout 1941 and early 1942.<ref name=noaa>{{cite web|url=http://sanctuaries.noaa.gov/missions/battleoftheatlantic2/bedfordshire.html|series=Battle of the Atlantic Expedition|title=HMT Bedfordshire|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=19 April 2010|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
==Situation in American waters deteriorates== After Germany declared war on the United States on 11 December 1941, German U-boats quickly became a deadly threat on the East Coast. The [[United States Navy]] was ill-prepared to defend against submarine warfare, and U-boats found it easy to pick off commercial shipping vessels, which traveled unescorted. The onslaught began with [[Operation Drumbeat]] when 35 Allied ships were sunk by U-boats off the American coast in January 1942.<ref>Hancock, p. 414.</ref>
In March 1942, the Royal Navy sent 24 converted trawlers, including ''Bedfordshire'', to assist the United States Navy with anti-submarine patrols along the East Coast.<ref name=Conn>Conn, p. 96.</ref> ''Bedfordshire'', commanded by Lieutenant Russell Bransby Davis, [[Royal Naval Reserve|RNR]], was assigned to the [[Fifth Naval District]], headquartered at [[Naval Station Norfolk]]. She operated out of [[Morehead City]], [[North Carolina]], primarily in sectors two and three, where she patrolled the waters surrounding the [[Outer Banks]]<ref name=uba4>{{cite web|url=http://www.uboatarchive.net/ESFWarDiaryApr42APP8.htm |title=Eastern Sea Patrol Log |publisher=uboatarchive.net |date=April 1942 |accessdate=26 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823044501/http://www.uboatarchive.net/ESFWarDiaryApr42APP8.htm |archivedate=23 August 2012 |df= }}</ref> while U-boats continued to terrorize local shipping.<ref name=Conn />
==Service on the American coast== On 16 April 1942, ''Bedfordshire'' along with HMT ''Lady Elsa'', {{HMS|Tourmaline|J339|6}}, and {{USS|Roper|DD-147|6}} conducted patrols in sector two.<ref name= uba4 /> ''Bedfordshire'' and ''Tourmaline'' assisted {{USS|Stringham|DD-83|6}} in the search for survivors of a sunken tanker in sector two on 17 April.<ref name=uba4 />
On 18 April, ''Bedfordshire'' searched for survivors of {{GS|U-85|1941|2}},<ref>{{cite book|title=Operation Drumbeat: Germany's U-Boat Attacks Along the American Coast in World War II|last=Gannon|first=Michael|date=2011|publisher=HarperCollins|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S1t91hzzsqEC|quote=By 0830 seven aircraft, including a blimp, were overhead and a British trawler, HMS ''Bedfordshire'', arrived to assist in recovering bodies.|isbn=9780062039064}}</ref> the first U-boat sunk by the US Navy off the East Coast.<ref>Conn, p. 97.</ref> For the next several days ''Bedfordshire'' stood guard duty over a concerted attempt to salvage ''U-85''. The effort was ultimately unsuccessful and the attempt was abandoned on 22 April.<ref name=uba4 />{{sfn|Blair|1996|p=543}} The remains of ''U-85'' lie at a depth of less than 100 feet (30 m) in the waters off Bodie Island Lighthouse; its [[Enigma machine]] was recovered in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hadley |first=Miles |publisher=Naval Historical Center |url=http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=6660 |title=Home Found for "Enigmatic" WW II U-boat Relic |date=5 April 2003 |accessdate=25 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904124232/http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=6660 |archivedate=4 September 2009 |df= }}</ref>
The remainder of April was spent patrolling in the vicinity of [[Currituck Island]], [[Hatteras Island]], and Lookout Shoals.<ref name=uba4 />
On 1 May, a plane reported having spotted a lifeboat some {{convert|255|nmi|km}} east of [[Cape Lookout (North Carolina)|Cape Lookout]], and ''Bedfordshire'' was sent on a search and rescue mission. She was back on patrol in sector three from 7–9 May, after which she returned to Morehead City.<ref>"Eastern Sea Patrol Log". May 1942. Retrieved 26 October 2012.</ref>
At noon on 10 May ''Bedfordshire'' and HMT ''St Zeno'' departed Morehead City to escort a convoy to Hatteras, arriving safely near midnight.<ref>{{cite book|title=In Some Foreign Field: The story of four British graves on the Outer Banks|first=L. VanLoan|last=Naisawald|year=1972|publisher=J.F. Blair|isbn=0910244650}}</ref>
==Sinking== On 10 May 1942, ''Bedfordshire'' and HMT ''St Loman'' were dispatched from Morehead City to search for a U-boat believed to be in the vicinity of Ocracoke Island. The ships were spotted by {{GS|U-558||2}}, commanded by ''[[Kapitänleutnant]]'' [[Günther Krech]]. Later in the evening Krech, believing his sub had been detected, fired on ''St Loman'', which spotted the torpedoes and evaded them. The search continued throughout the night. At 05:40 on 11 May 1942, ''U-558'' fired a torpedo at ''Bedfordshire'', missed, and fired a second, which scored a direct hit and sank her immediately. All 37 men aboard were killed.{{sfn|Blair|1996|p=574}}<ref>Hickam, p. 205.</ref> A 38th crewman, a young [[Stoker (occupation)|stoker]] named Sam Nutt, had been detained at Morehead City by local police and narrowly missed boarding the ship for her last patrol.<ref name=HTN>{{cite web|url=http://www.harry-tates.org.uk/veteranstales4.htm|title=HMS Bedfordshire one of the 24 British trawlers sent to help the United States|publisher=Harry Tate's Navy|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
[[File:HMT Bedfordshire.jpg|thumb|right|Commemorative plaque at British Cemetery, Ocracoke Island]] On 14 May, the bodies of two seamen were discovered by a [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guardsman]] on the shores of Ocracoke Island. Their British uniforms offered the first indication that ''Bedfordshire'' may have met her end, and the U-boat menace was presumed to be responsible.<ref name="Hickam, p. 207">Hickam, p. 207.</ref> Her fate was confirmed the following year after ''U-558'' was sunk, resulting in the capture of Kapitänleutnant Krech and his ship's diaries.<ref name=HTN />
==Burials== The bodies found on 14 May were identified as belonging to Sub-Lieutenant Thomas Cunningham and Ordinary Telegraphist Stanley Craig of the ''Bedfordshire''. They were buried in a small plot next to a cemetery in Ocracoke Village. The [[White Ensign|Royal Navy flag]] draped over Cunningham's coffin was one of several that he himself had given to a local man less than a month earlier for the funeral ceremonies of British seamen.<ref name="Hickam, p. 207"/><ref name="Runyan, p. 163">Runyan, p. 163.</ref> Shortly thereafter, two additional bodies from the ship washed ashore on Ocracoke. Unidentified, they were also buried in what became known as the Ocracoke Island British Cemetery.<ref name=OBC>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/2073156/OCRACOKE%20ISLAND%20(BRITISH)%20CEMETERY|title=Ocracoke Island (British) Cemetery|publisher=Commonwealth War Graves Commission|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
On nearby [[Hatteras Island]], the body of a fifth British seaman, unidentifiable but presumed to be from ''Bedfordshire'', washed ashore on 21 May. The month prior, the body of another British sailor from the sunken merchant ship ''San Delfino'' had been buried on Hatteras; the ''Bedfordshire'' sailor's body was interred in an adjacent plot, resulting in a second British Cemetery, formally known as Cape Hatteras Coast Guard Burial Ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/2112362/CAPE%20HATTERAS%20(U.S.%20COAST%20GUARD)%20BURIAL%20GROUND|title=Cape Hatteras (U.S. Coast Guard) Burial Ground|publisher=Commonwealth War Graves Commission|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
In late May or early June, a sixth body, belonging to Seaman Alfred Dryden, washed ashore at [[Swan Quarter, North Carolina]]. It was buried in Oak Grove Baptist Cemetery at Creeds, Virginia, with three of the dead from HMT ''Kingston Ceylonite'', sunk by a mine on 15 June 1942, whose bodies washed ashore nearby.<ref name=noaa /><ref name=OGC>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2720081/DRYDEN,%20ALFRED|title=Casualty details: Alfred Dryden|publisher=Commonwealth War Graves Commission|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
==Commemoration== The British Cemeteries on Ocracoke and Hatteras were leased in 1976 in perpetuity to the British government for as long as the interred bodies remain there.<ref name=OBC /> Formal custody is handled by the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]], which provides the protocol headstones. Regular maintenance is handled by the US Coast Guard and local residents as a gesture of gratitude and respect to the fallen men and an act of comity to the British government. A Royal Navy flag flies over the cemeteries, and a ceremony is held there each year on 11 May to honor the men of the ''Bedfordshire''.<ref>[http://www.offbeattravel.com/british-cemetery-outerbanks.html Offbeat travel:British Cemetery at Ocracoke, North Carolina]</ref> The Commonwealth War Graves Commission also provided headstones for the four British servicemen interred in Creeds, Virginia, including Alfred Dryden of the ''Bedfordshire''.<ref name=OGC />
The crewmen whose bodies were not recovered are honored by name on the Royal Naval Patrol Service Memorial at [[Lowestoft]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rnps.lowestoft.org.uk/memorial/memorial_vessel1.htm|publisher=Royal Naval Patrol Service|title=Royal Naval Patrol Service Memorial by Vessel|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref>
The wreck of the ''Bedfordshire'' was located in 1980 at {{coord|34|10|N|76|41|W|display=inline,title}} at a depth of {{convert|100|ft}}.<ref name=uboat.net /> The site is considered a protected [[war grave]] under the [[Protection of Military Remains Act 1986]]. In 2008 and 2009 the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] led an expedition to document the condition of ships sunk during the [[Battle of the Atlantic]]. At the request of the British government, the ''Bedfordshire'' wreck site was surveyed by the expedition in 2009.<ref name=noaa /><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ecu.edu/cs-cas/maritime/upload/S2S_Fall09.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=East Carolina University|title=Preserving the Memory of the Battle of the Atlantic through Maritime Archaeology|page=19|author=Wagner, John|journal=Stem to Stern|date=January 2010|issue=volume 26}}</ref>
On 31 July 2015, the ''Bedfordshire'' was listed in the US government's [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/listings/20150807.htm|publisher=National Park Service|title=Weekly List for August 7, 2015|accessdate=9 August 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Torpedo Alley (North Carolina)]] *[[Trawlers of the Royal Navy]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|biological immortality}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox anatomy | Name = Immortalized cell line | Image = HeLa-IV.jpg | Caption = Scanning electron micrograph of an apoptotic HeLa cell. Zeiss Merlin HR-SEM. | Image2 = HeLa Hoechst 33258.jpg | Caption2 = [[HeLa]] cells, an example of an immortalised cell line. DIC image, DNA stained with [[Hoechst stain|Hoechst 33258]]. | Precursor = }} An '''immortalized cell line''' is a population of [[cell (biology)|cell]]s from a [[multicellular organism]] which would normally not proliferate indefinitely but, due to [[mutation]], have evaded normal [[cellular senescence]] and instead can keep undergoing division. The cells can therefore be grown for prolonged periods ''[[in vitro]]''. The mutations required for immortality can occur naturally or be intentionally induced for experimental purposes. Immortal cell lines are a very important tool for research into the [[biochemistry]] and [[cell biology]] of multicellular organisms. Immortalised cell lines have also found uses in [[biotechnology]].
An immortalized cell line should not be confused with [[stem cell]]s, which can also divide indefinitely, but form a normal part of the development of a multicellular organism.
==Relation to natural biology and pathology== There are various immortal cell lines. Some of them are normal cell lines (e.g. derived from stem cells). Other immortalised cell lines are the ''[[in vitro]]'' equivalent of [[cancer]]ous cells. Cancer occurs when a [[somatic cell]] which normally cannot divide undergoes mutations which cause de-regulation of the normal [[cell cycle]] controls leading to uncontrolled proliferation. Immortalised cell lines have undergone similar mutations allowing a cell type which would normally not be able to divide to be proliferated ''in vitro''. The origins of some immortal cell lines, for example [[HeLa]] human cells, are from naturally occurring cancers.
==Role and uses== Immortalized cell lines are widely used as a simple model for more complex biological systems, for example for the analysis of the [[biochemistry]] and [[cell biology]] of [[mammalian]] (including [[human]]) cells.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cell lines|journal=Spermatogenesis|volume=2|issue=1|pages=1–5|pmc=3341241|year=2012|author1=Kaur|first1=G|last2=Dufour|first2=J. M|doi=10.4161/spmg.19885|pmid=22553484}}</ref> The main advantage of using an immortal cell line for research is its immortality; the cells can be grown indefinitely in culture. This simplifies analysis of the biology of cells which may otherwise have a limited lifetime.
Immortalized cell lines can also be cloned giving rise to a [[clonal population]] which can, in turn, be propagated indefinitely. This allows an analysis to be repeated many times on genetically identical cells, which is desirable for repeatable scientific experiments. The alternative, performing an analysis on primary cells from multiple tissue donors, does not have this advantage.
Immortalized cell lines find use in biotechnology, where they are a cost-effective way of growing cells similar to those found in a multicellular organism ''in vitro''. The cells are used for a wide variety of purposes, from testing [[toxicity]] of compounds or drugs to production of eukaryotic proteins.
===Limitations===
====Changes from nonimmortal origins==== While immortalized cell lines often originate from a well-known tissue type, they have undergone significant mutations to become immortal. This can alter the biology of the cell and must be taken into consideration in any analysis. Further, cell lines can change genetically over multiple passages, leading to phenotypic differences among isolates and potentially different experimental results depending on when and with what strain isolate an experiment is conducted.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marx|first=Vivien|date=29 April 2014|title=Cell-line authentication demystified|department=Technology Feature|journal=[[Nat. Methods|Nature Methods]]|type=Paper "Nature Reprint Collection, Technology Features" (Nov 2014)|volume=11|issue=5|pages=483|doi=10.1038/nmeth.2932|pmid=<!--could not find-->}}</ref>
====Contamination with other cells==== {{Main|List of contaminated cell lines}} Many cell lines that are widely used for [[biomedical research]] have been [[Cell culture#Cell line cross-contamination|contaminated]] and overgrown by other, more aggressive cells. For example, supposed thyroid lines were actually melanoma cells, supposed prostate tissue was actually bladder cancer, and supposed normal uterine cultures were actually breast cancer.<ref name="Science">{{cite journal | title =Line of attack | journal =Science | date =27 February 2015 | author =Jill Neimark | volume =347 | issue =6225 | pages =938–940 | url =http://www.sciencemag.org/content/347/6225/938.full | doi =10.1126/science.347.6225.938 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
==Methods of generation== There are several methods for generating immortalized cell lines:<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Matin|first2=M. M.|last3=Bahrami|first3=A. R.|last4=Ghasroldasht|first4=M. M.|year=2013|title=Immortality of cell lines: Challenges and advantages of establishment|journal=[[Cell Biol. Int.|Cell Biology International]]|volume=37|issue=10|pages=1038–45|doi=10.1002/cbin.10137|pmc=|pmid=23723166|last1=Irfan Maqsood|first1=M.}}</ref> # Isolation from a naturally occurring cancer. This is the original method for generating an immortalized cell line. Major examples include human [[HeLa]] cells that were obtained from a [[cervical cancer]], mouse Raw 264.7 cells that were subjected to [[mutagenesis]] and then selected for cells which are able to undergo division.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} # Introduction of a viral gene that partially deregulates the cell cycle (e.g., the adenovirus type 5 E1 gene was used to immortalize the [[HEK 293]] cell line; the [[Epstein-Barr virus]] can immortalize [[B lymphocyte]]s by infection<ref name="pmid6261650">{{cite journal |vauthors=Henle W, Henle G |title=Epidemiologic aspects of Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)-associated diseases |journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences |volume=354 |issue= |pages=326–31 |year=1980 |pmid=6261650 |doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1980.tb27975.x}}</ref>). # Artificial [[Gene expression|expression]] of key [[protein]]s required for immortality, for example [[telomerase]] which prevents degradation of [[chromosome]] ends during DNA replication in eukaryotes # [[Hybridoma technology]], specifically used for the generation of immortalized [[antibody]]-producing [[B cell]] lines, where an antibody-producing B cell is fused with a [[myeloma]] (B cell cancer) cell.
===Examples=== There are several examples of immortalized cell lines, each with different properties. Most immortalized cell lines are classified by the cell type they originated from or are most similar to biologically. * [[3T3 cells]] – a mouse [[fibroblast]] cell line derived from a spontaneous mutation in cultured mouse embryo tissue. * [[A549 cell]]s – derived from a cancer patient [[lung]] tumor. * [[HeLa]] cells – a widely used human cell line isolated from cervical cancer patient [[Henrietta Lacks]]. * [[HEK 293 cells]] – derived from human fetal cells. * [[Jurkat]] cells – a human [[T lymphocyte]] cell line isolated from a case of leukemia. * [[Vero cell]]s – a monkey [[kidney]] cell line that arose by spontaneous immortalisation.
==See also== *[[List of breast cancer cell lines]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.atcc.org/ [[ATCC (company)|ATCC]]] - American Type Culture Collection *[https://web.expasy.org/cellosaurus/ [[Cellosaurus]] - a knowledge resource on cell lines] *[http://www.cellbankaustralia.com/ CellBank Australia - Australia's national not-for-profit cell line repository]

{{other ships|Japanese submarine I-55}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= [[Empire of Japan]] |Ship flag=[[Image:Naval Ensign of Japan.svg|60px]] |Ship name=I-55 |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1943 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= April 20, 1944 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate= Disputed (see article) |Ship status= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[I-52-class submarine (1942)|Type C3 submarine]] |Ship displacement=*{{Convert|2564|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} surfaced *{{Convert|3644|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|108.7|m|ftin|abbr=on}} overall |Ship beam= {{convert|9.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|5.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship power=*{{convert|4700|bhp|lk=in|abbr=on}} (diesel) *{{convert|1200|hp|abbr=on}} ([[electric motor]]) |Ship propulsion=*[[Diesel-electric]] *1 × [[diesel engine]] *1 × electric motor |Ship speed=*{{convert|17.7|kn|lk=in}} surfaced *{{convert|6.5|kn}} submerged |Ship range=*{{convert|27000|nmi|abbr=on|lk=in}} at {{convert|12|kn}} surfaced *{{convert|105|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|3|kn}} submerged |Ship crew=94 |Ship test depth={{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship armament=*6 × bow {{convert|533|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tubes]] *2 × [[14 cm/40 11th Year Type naval gun|{{convert|14|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}]] [[deck gun]] *1 × twin [[Type 96 25 mm AT/AA Gun|{{convert|25|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} Type 96]] [[anti-aircraft gun]]s |Ship notes= }} |} The '''Japanese submarine ''I-55''''' was one of three [[Type C submarine|Type C]] [[cruiser submarine]]s of the C3 [[ship class|sub-class]] built for the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] (IJN) during the 1940s.
==Design and description== The Type C3 submarines were derived from the earlier C2 sub-class although with fewer [[torpedo tube]]s, an additional [[deck gun]], and less-powerful engines to extend their range. They [[Displacement (ship)|displaced]] {{Convert|2564|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} surfaced and {{Convert|3644|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} submerged. The submarines were {{convert|108.7|m|ftin|sp=us}} long, had a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|9.3|m|ftin|sp=us}} and a [[draft (hull)|draft]] of {{convert|5.1|m|ftin|sp=us}}. They had a diving depth of {{convert|100|m|ft|sp=us}}.<ref name=b4>Bagnasco, p. 192</ref>
For surface running, the boats were powered by two {{convert|2350|bhp|lk=in|0|adj=on}} [[diesel engine]]s, each driving one [[propeller shaft]]. When submerged each propeller was driven by a {{convert|600|hp|0|adj=on}} [[electric motor]]. They could reach {{convert|17.7|kn|lk=in}} on the surface and {{convert|6.5|kn}} underwater.<ref name=c5>Chesneau, p. 201</ref> On the surface, the ''C3''s had a range of {{convert|27000|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|12|kn}}; submerged, they had a range of {{convert|105|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|3|kn}}.<ref name=cd3/>
The boats were armed with six internal bow {{convert|53.3|cm|in|1|abbr=on|sp=us}} torpedo tubes and carried a total of 19 [[torpedo]]es. They were also armed with two [[14 cm/40 11th Year Type naval gun|{{convert|140|mm|in|abbr=on}}/40]] deck guns and one twin mount for [[Type 96 25 mm AT/AA Gun|{{convert|25|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} Type 96]] [[anti-aircraft gun]]s.<ref name=cd3>Carpenter & Dorr, p. 110</ref>
==Construction and career== Assigned to the defense of the Marianas, during a mission to rescue staff of the 1st Air Fleet on [[Tinian]], she was presumably found and sunk by the [[USS Gilmer (APD-11)|USS ''Gilmer'']] and [[USS William C. Miller (DE-259)|USS ''William C. Miller'']] on 14 July 1944, though some sources claim this sinking was actually the [[Japanese submarine Ro-48|Ro-48]].
See also [[USS Wyman (DE-38)|USS ''Wyman'']] and [[USS Reynolds (DE-42)|USS ''Reynolds'']] references to the sinking of this submarine in which Wyman claims credit for this sinking on 28 July 1944.
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== *{{cite book|last=Bagnasco |first=Erminio |title=Submarines of World War Two |year=1977 |publisher=Naval Institute Press |location=Annapolis, Maryland |isbn=0-87021-962-6}} *{{cite book|last1=Boyd|first1=Carl|last2=Yoshida|first2=Akikiko|title=The Japanese Submarine Force and World War II|date=2002|publisher=Naval Institute Press|location=Annapolis, Maryland|isbn=1-55750-015-0|lastauthoramp=y}} *{{cite book|last1=Carpenter|first1=Dorr B.|last2=Polmar|first2=Norman|title=Submarines of the Imperial Japanese Navy 1904–1945|year=1986|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-396-6|lastauthoramp=y}} *{{cite book|title=Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922–1946|editor1-last=Chesneau|editor1-first=Roger|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=Greenwich, UK|year=1980|isbn=0-85177-146-7}} *{{cite book|last=Hashimoto|first=Mochitsura|others=Colegrave, E.H.M. (translator)|title=Sunk: The Story of the Japanese Submarine Fleet 1942 – 1945|publisher=Cassell and Company|location=London|year=1954|id=ASIN B000QSM3L0}} *{{cite book|last=Stille|first=Mark|title=Imperial Japanese Navy Submarines 1941-45| series =New Vanguard|volume=135|year=2007|publisher=Osprey Publishing|location=Botley, Oxford, UK|isbn=978-1-84603-090-1}}
==External links== * [http://www.combinedfleet.com/I-55.htm Tabular movements of submarine I-55] * [http://www.warsailors.com/phorum/read.php?f=1&i=16739&t=16739 warsailors.com]

'''Johann Adam''' (c.1705 – 13 November 1779) was a German [[violist]] and [[composer]] of [[Baroque]] era.
==Life== Little is known about Johann Adam's early years and his birth year is an estimate. In 1733, he was listed as a ''Jagdpfeiffer'' at the Royal court in [[Dresden]].<ref name="Van Boer" /> In 1737<ref name="Fürstenau" /> he was transferred to the [[Hofkapelle]] as a violist with a yearly salary of 400 thaler.<ref name="Eitner" /> From around 1740,<ref name="Van Boer" /> he was also well known as a composer of ballet music which was played during operas, particularly those of Hasse,<ref name="Fürstenau" /> and from 1763 to 1769, he was employed as the director and composer of the Elector's French Theater.<ref name="Van Boer" /> In 1775, Charles Burney said of him "Mr. Adam, a veteran musicien, one of the few remaining performers in the celebrated opera-band, under the direction of Signor Hasse, has established himself a great reputation by his composition of the music to the dances performed at this opera in its most flourishing state".<ref name="Burney" />
==Works== Many of Adam's compositions have been lost. Below is a list of his known works which are listed in RISM.<ref name="RISM" /> As well as these, there are several movements of ballet music inserted into operas which also survive.
*Oboe Concerto in B-flat major *Oboe Concerto in G major (also attributed to [[Andrea Bernasconi|Bernasconi]] as a Flute Concerto) *Flute Concerto in D major *Flute Concerto in G major (previously attributed to [[Johann Joachim Quantz|Quantz]] as QV5: Anh.22) *Harpsichord Concerto in F major *Concerto for 2 flutes in G major *Concerto for 2 flutes in C major *Sinfonia in G major for strings (without violas) and continuo *Sinfonia in D major for strings and continuo *Sinfonia in F major for strings and continuo (also attributed to [[Giovanni Battista Sammartini]] as JenS D36]] ; also in a version for strings, 2 flutes, 2 horns, 2 bassoons and continuo *Jagd Sinfonia in D major for strings,2 horns and continuo *Sinfonia in D major for strings, 2 horns, bassoon and continuo *Partita in B-flat major for strings (without violas), 2 oboes and continuo *Partita in E-flat major for strings, 2 oboes and continuo *Sonata for 2 flutes in G major *Ballet Music ''La Tempête'' (only flute parts surviving) *Sacred Cantata ''Wie lieblich sind deine Wohnungen'' (composed 1735 or before) *Polonaise ''Fackel-Tanz'' for 2 oboes, 2 horns, 2 violins and continuo *''Recueil d'airs à danser execute's sur le Théâtre du Roi à Dresde accommode's pour le clavecin'' (Published Leipzig Johann Gottlob Immanuel Breitkopf, 1756)
Among his missing works are a Flute Concerto in C major,<ref name="Breitkopf" /> 3 Oboe Concertos,<ref name="Breitkopf" /> Minuet from 1769,<ref name="Breitkopf" /> a Sinfonia in F major,<ref name="Breitkopf" /><ref name="Ringmacher" /> a Bassoon Concerto,<ref name="Ringmacher" /> a Trio for violin or flute and harp.<ref name="Ringmacher" />

'''Katherine Bellenden''' (1497 – c.1568) was a courtier working in the wardrobe of [[James V of Scotland]]. Her niece of the same name was similarly employed.
==A family at court== Katherine was the daughter of Patrick Bellenden a servant of [[Margaret Tudor]] and Mariota Douglas, who was the nurse of James V. Her older brother was the Justice Clerk [[Thomas Bellenden of Auchnoule]], another brother was the priest, poet, and translator [[John Bellenden]].<ref>Van Heijnsbergen, Theo, 'Literature in Queen Mary's Edinburgh: the Bannatyne Manuscript', in, ''The Renaissance in Scotland'', Brill (1994), p.191-6</ref>
Katherine married Adam Hopper (d.1529)<ref>Durkan, John, ed., ''Protocol Book of Thomas Foular'', SRS New Series 10 (1985), p.34 no.98, p.49 no.141</ref> in 1527 receiving a royal gift of £300 as a dowry or "tochter" in thanks for her mother's service,<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol.5 (1903), p.330</ref> then [[Francis Bothwell]], who were both merchants and [[List of Lord Provosts of Edinburgh|Provosts of Edinburgh]]. In 1529 Adam and Francis were business partners exporting fish to England.<ref>''Letters & Papers Henry VIII'', vol.4 (1875), no.5059</ref> Her third husband was [[Oliver Sinclair]], the King's favourite, who was reputed to have caused the Scottish defeat at the [[battle of Solway Moss]].
==Sewing for the Stewarts== While Katherine worked in the royal wardrobe she bought cambric cloth, Holland cloth, and other materials for making the King's shirts, which she and her colleague Janet Douglas, the King's seamstress, embroidered with gold and silver thread. She sold cloth to the King's tailor, Thomas Arthur, and kept accounts of the King's purse. Janet Douglas, like Katherine, married a prominent courtier, [[David Lyndsay|David Lindsay of the Mount]] a diplomat and poet.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 6, HM General Register House (1905), 298, 380-381, 390.</ref>
In July 1537 Katherine, described as "Master Francis Bothuilis wyfe" delivered 10 ells of purple velvet for use at the funeral of the Queen, [[Madeleine of Valois]].<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', Edinburgh (1905), p.332 ('tyrement': funeral)</ref> Amongst the many payments to "Katherine Bellenden" in the Scottish treasurer's accounts one entry notes Katherine as the spouse of Robert Craig, a servant of the tailor Thomas Arthur.<ref>''Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland'', vol. 7 (1907), p.463.</ref> This was Katherine's namesake niece, daughter of Thomas Bellenden of Auchnoule, married to Robert Craig, later an Edinburgh merchant, and their children included [[John Craig (physician)|John Craig]] the physician and perhaps the lawyer [[Thomas Craig (poet)|Sir Thomas Craig]]. It seems that both Katherines were employed in the royal wardrobe and dealt in luxury fabrics.<ref>Sanderson, Margaret H.B., ''A Kindly Place?'', Tuckwell (2002), p.108.</ref>
==Family finances== James V paid Katherine £666-13s-4d in April 1538, this was for 1000 marks which she had lent to the King's mother, [[Margaret Tudor]]. In 1541, Oliver and Katherine with their kinsfolk and their royal wardrobe colleagues, [[John Tennent]] and his wife the royal laundress, Mause Acheson, made a contract 'mortifyng' property, including the rents of part of a property on Edinburgh's [[Royal Mile|Netherbow]] to the west of [[Moubray House]] for priests to say Mass for their souls in [[St Giles Cathedral|St Giles, Edinburgh]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0c_AAAAcAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Laing, David, ed., ''Registrum cartarum Ecclesie Sancti Egidii de Edinburgh'', Bannatyne Club, (1859)] pp.246-253 no.141: ''Register of the Great Seal of Scotland, 1513-1546'', HM General Register House (1883) p.597 no. 2600 (Latin).</ref>
In November 1543, Katherine wrote to the Queen Dowager of Scotland, [[Mary of Guise]], regarding her and her husband's debts. A ship they had invested in had been impounded for sums of money they owed for lands in Orkney and Shetland. Mary of Guise was giving their Orkney lands to [[George Gordon, 4th Earl of Huntly|George Gordon]], [[Earl of Huntly]]. In Orkney, Oliver Sinclair held the castle of [[Kirkwall]] as his ancestors had done, and Katherine wrote, 'we think great lack to go from our native rooms which my husband and his surname have held these three or four hundred years.'<ref>Cameron, Annie I., ed., ''The Scottish Correspondence of Mary of Lorraine'', SHS, (1927), pp.46-7.</ref>
==Children== Katherine and Adam Hopper had a son, Richard, who was eldest and heir to Adam Hopper after he died in 1530.<ref>''Protocol Book of John Foular, 1528-34'', SRS (1985), 65-6, no.198</ref> Francis Bothwell was the father of [[Adam Bothwell]], [[Bishop of Orkney]], though it is unclear if Katherine was his mother.
Katherine had two daughters with Oliver Sinclair. Isobel Sinclair married [[James Hamilton (assassin)|James Hamilton of Bothwellhaugh]] who assassinated [[Regent Moray]] in 1570. Alison Sinclair married David Hamilton of Monktonmains, brother of Bothwellhaugh. The persons of Isobel Sinclair and her supposed cousin Anne Bothwell are conflated in the Scottish ballad, ''Lady Anne Bothwell's Lament''. Anne Bothwell was the daughter of Adam Bothwell the bishop, and perhaps granddaughter of Katherine Bellenden. The ballad relates to her seduction and abandonment by Alexander Erskine (d.1640), a son of the [[John Erskine, Earl of Mar (1558–1634)|Earl of Mar]]<ref>Maidment, James, ed., ''Scottish ballads and songs, historical and traditionary'', vol. 2, Edinburgh (1868), 39, 41-2, 327.</ref>
==External links== * As part of the restoration of the Palace at [[Stirling Castle]], [[Historic Scotland]] has dramatised Katherine's role in the royal wardrobe; [http://www.stirlingcastle.gov.uk/katherinebellenden Historic Scotland - Katherine Bellenden]

{{Infobox professional wrestler | name = Lenny Montana | image = | caption = | birth_name = Leonardo Passafaro | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|3|13|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1992|5|12|1926|3|13|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Lindenhurst, New York]], U.S. | death_cause = [[Myocardial infarction]] | names = Lenny Montana
Lenny Passaforo
Len Crosby
Len Montana
Chief Chewacki
The Zebra Kid | height = 6 ft 6 in | weight = 235 lb | billed = [[San Francisco, California]] | debut = 1953 | retired = 1972 }} '''Lenny Montana''' (born '''Leonardo Passafaro'''; March 13, 1926 – May 12, 1992) was an American actor who played the role of feared hitman [[Luca Brasi]] in ''[[The Godfather]]''. Prior to becoming an actor, he had a successful career as a [[professional wrestler]]{{cite web|title=Lenny Montana|url=http://www.obsessedwithwrestling.com/profiles/l/lenny-montana.php|publisher=Obsessed with Wrestling|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202162039/http://www.obsessedwithwrestling.com/profiles/l/lenny-montana.php|archivedate=2008-12-02|df=}} as well as an enforcer for the [[Colombo crime family|Colombo family]].{{cite news|first1=Ron|last1=Cassie|accessdate=2018-05-07|title=What's it like From mob to God|url=https://www.fredericknewspost.com/archive/what-s-it-like-from-mob-to-god/article_025b3a38-62a3-5c52-be79-bd26dafd5e7a.html|newspaper=[[Frederick News-Post|The Frederick News-Post]]|date=2008-10-02}} == Biography == === Early life and early wrestling career=== He was born in Brooklyn, New York City in 1926 of [[Italian-American]] heritage. He was fluent in both [[English language|English]] and [[Italian language|Italian]]. His wrestling career began in neighboring [[New Jersey]] in 1953. He wrestled under the '''[[Zebra Kid]]''' gimmick, and was billed at the height of 6 foot 6 inches. It wasn't long before Montana found success. Along with Golden Terror, he won the New Jersey Tag Team titles on April 4, 1953.{{cite web|title=Lenny Montana|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/l/lenny-montana.html|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}} Lenny began to travel on the road, wrestling in the [[Midwest]]. He soon won the [[NWA Central States Heavyweight Championship]], defeating Dave Sims on October 1, 1953 in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]]. However he lost the title on December 11, 1953 to [[Sonny Myers]],{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/s/sonny-myers.html |title=Sonny Myers |publisher=Online World of Wrestling |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} who had held the title a previous three times before defeating the Zebra Kid. His final success of the 1950s came in 1956, winning the [[NWA Texas Tag Team Championship]] with [[Gene Kiniski]], defeating Herb Freeman and [[Ray Gunkel]] on September 18 in [[Dallas]] under the alias Len Crosby. He also worked as a [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]] during this time to earn extra money. === Later wrestling career=== By the late 1950s, Montana was on the road with the [[Carnival]] Circuit as a wrestler. As a popular wrestler within the circuit, Montana met the then unknown [[Eddie Sharkey]] in 1960.{{cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/Colosseum/Arena/9893/sharkey2.htm |title=Tom Zenk - first trainer - Eddie Sharkey part 2 |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2009-10-28 |accessdate=2014-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028153230/http://www.geocities.com/Colosseum/Arena/9893/sharkey2.htm |archivedate=October 28, 2009 }} The two struck up a friendship. After seeing what Sharkey could do, Montana recommended that he try his hand at professional wrestling. Montana also clued in Sharkey on the then-unacknowledged truth about professional wrestling, that all the outcomes are predetermined. Later on in that year, Montana won the NWA Texas World Tag Team titles with Joe Christie, under the Len Crosby name. Then with [[Hard Boiled Haggerty]], he won the AWA World Tag Team Championship on October 4, 1960, defeating Stan Kowalski and Tiny Mills ( wrestling as Murder Inc.) in [[Minneapolis]].{{cite web|url=http://wrestling.johnny-o.net/bios/?id=560 |title=Lenny Montana | Johnny O's Wrestling Website |publisher=Wrestling.johnny-o.net |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} But in a match against [[Verne Gagne]], Montana suffered a broken leg, forcing Haggerty to choose a new partner.{{cite web|url=http://wrestling.johnny-o.net/titles/history.php?title=awa_tag |title=A.W.A. World Tag Team | Johnny O's Wrestling Website |publisher=Wrestling.johnny-o.net |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} After recovering from his injury, in 1961 Montana began to wrestle in [[Florida]]. He came to the [[Tampa Bay]] area and began to wrestle under The Zebra Kid alias.{{cite web|url=http://www.teddwebb.com/wrestling_hall_of_fame/lenny_montana.html |title=Wrestling Hall Of Fame |publisher=Teddwebb.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} At his great size, he would often pin his opponents in under one minute. The Zebra Kid had a notable feud with [[Eddie Graham]]; their battles sold out [[Fort Homer Hesterly Armory]] many Tuesday nights in 1961. Things came to a head when Montana defeated Eddie Graham in a [[NWA Southern Heavyweight Championship (Georgia version)]] title match on May 1, 1962.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news2008/1209764213.shtml |title=Wrestling News and Results, WWE News, TNA News, ROH News |publisher=Wrestleview.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} On November 23, 1962, he won the NWA (Georgia) Southern Tag Team Titles with his partner [[Gypsy Joe]], defeating 'Grizzly' Jake Smith and Luke Brown. Montana then went on to form a powerful partnership with [[Tarzan Tyler]], in which they would win three titles. First, the [[NWA International Tag Team Championship (Georgia version)|NWA International Tag Team Titles]] on April 9, 1963{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news2008/1209159472.shtml |title=Wrestling News and Results, WWE News, TNA News, ROH News |publisher=Wrestleview.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} defeating Ted Evans and Chief Little Eagle, then again winning the NWA International Tag Team Titles later in June 1963, defeating billed champions Chief Little Eagle and Dick Steinborn. Finally, the duo won the NWA World Tag Team Championship in Georgia, during October 1963, they defeated Karl Von Brauner and Kurt Von Brauner. Montana was due to be Gorilla Monsoon's [[tag team]] partner in 1964, but it never happened due to Monsoon becoming partners with The African Savage at the last minute. Lenny had been interested in acting, and was meeting with casting agents in [[Los Angeles]] at the same time he was due to team up with Bison.{{cite web|url=http://buddybison.com/ |title=WELCOME TO THE WEBSITE OF BUDDY BISON aka EXECUTIONER #2 aka HURRICANE CHANDLER |publisher=Buddybison.com |date=2012-08-14 |accessdate=2014-01-28}} Montana began to wrestle less and less, and went into semi-retirement; however he appeared in matches up until his acting career took off in the early 1970s. === Working for the Colombo crime family=== Montana became involved with the [[Colombo crime family]] in the late 1960s. Tall and very heavily built, his talents were mostly as an enforcer and an [[arson]]ist. He would tie a [[tampon]] to the tail of a mouse, dip it in [[kerosene]], light it, and let the mouse run through a building, or he would put a [[candle]] in front of a [[cuckoo clock]] so that when the clock's bird would pop out the candle would be knocked over and start a fire.{{cite web|last=Seal |first=Mark |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2009/03/godfather200903?currentPage=all |title=The Godfather Wars |publisher=Vanity Fair |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} Eventually, Montana ended up doing time in [[Rikers Island|Riker's Island.]]{{cite web|title=Why the gangsters still love The Godfather of all movies|date=April 13, 2001|url=http://www.independent.ie/woman/celeb-news/why-the-gangsters-still-love-the-godfather-of-all-movies-26089900.html|work=[[Irish Independent]]}} Upon being released, as a friend of the family, Montana would act as a [[bodyguard]] for many of the senior members of the Colombo Family. === Work on ''The Godfather''=== The filming of the classic movie ''[[The Godfather]]'' faced strong opposition from the [[Italian-American Civil Rights League]], with disputes headed by [[Joseph Colombo|Joe Colombo]] and [[Frank Sinatra]], threatening its whole production. Producer [[Al Ruddy]] eventually made a deal with the league and Joe Colombo to cut the word Mafia from the script, and the league were behind the production of the film. This meant many mobsters would be present on the set of ''The Godfather''. It was in 1971, when Montana was acting as a bodyguard for a senior Colombo Family member,{{cite web |url=http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/news/leave-the-gun-take-the-cannoli-and-other-godfather-stories.php |title=‘Leave the Gun. Take the Cannoli,’ and Other Godfather Stories |publisher=Filmschoolrejects.com |date=2009-02-08 |accessdate=2014-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110003809/http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/news/leave-the-gun-take-the-cannoli-and-other-godfather-stories.php |archivedate=2014-01-10 |df= }} that he met Francis Ford Coppola and Al Ruddy. After being introduced to the 6-foot-6, 320-pound Montana, they quickly cast him for the role of [[Luca Brasi]]. When Bettye McCartt, Al Ruddy's assistant, broke her watch, Montana offered to get her a new one. A week later, Montana returned with a "gift from the boys" – an antique diamond watch. He was picked for the part after the original actor playing the character died of a [[stroke]].[http://www.casperstartribune.net/articles/2006/03/27/news/national/4c88e582fc58a6b88725713e000749f0.txt Casperstartribune.net] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614050303/http://www.casperstartribune.net/articles/2006/03/27/news/national/4c88e582fc58a6b88725713e000749f0.txt |date=June 14, 2009 }} This would be his first film appearance. His role was that of sadistic mob enforcer Luca Brasi, a [[hitman]] used by [[Vito Corleone|Don Corleone]] ([[Marlon Brando]]). Montana was so nervous about appearing opposite Brando that he kept practicing his lines over and over again. [[Francis Ford Coppola]] rewrote the scene to feature this.[http://www.nerve.com/CS/blogs/screengrab/archive/2008/09/26/that-guy-special-quot-godfather-quot-edition-part-five.aspx Nerve.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122024650/http://www.nerve.com/CS/blogs/screengrab/archive/2008/09/26/that-guy-special-quot-godfather-quot-edition-part-five.aspx |date=2008-11-22 }} Montana also suffered an attack of nerves during the scene where his character thanked the Don; Coppola also wrote this into the script as Brasi being overwhelmed by the Don's invitation to his daughter's wedding. He had little screen time in the role of Luca Brasi, but his notable height and physique caught the eye of producers, and he appeared in several movies and television programs after appearing in ''The Godfather''. === Film and TV career=== After appearing in ''The Godfather'', Montana was an actor in demand. One of the first of these roles was the Italian [[satire|spoof]] film ''[[The Funny Face of the Godfather]]'' in 1973. Montana had the role of Saro, and an artist's rendition of Montana appeared on the film's poster.{{cite web|url=http://i210.photobucket.com/albums/bb96/DaveTyla/lenny21.png|title=i210.photobucket.com|publisher=}} He established himself as an efficient [[character actor]] and appeared in ''[[Patty (film)|Patty]]'' (1976), ''[[Fingers (1978 film)|Fingers]]'' (1978) as the pizzeria owner Luchino, ''[[Matilda (1978 film)|Matilda]]'' (1978), ''[[They Went That-A-Way & That-A-Way]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=92853&atid=0 |title=They Went That-a-Way & That-a-Way (1978) - Overview |publisher=TCM.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} (1978), ''[[The Jerk]]'' (1979), ''[[Seven (1979 film)|Seven]]'' (1979), ''Below the Belt'' (1980), ''[[Defiance (1980 film)|Defiance]]'' (1980), ''[[Battle Creek Brawl]]'' (1980) alongside [[Jackie Chan]], ''[[Evilspeak]]'' (1981), ''[[...All the Marbles]]'' (1981), ''[[Pandemonium (film)|Pandemonium]]'' (1982) and ''[[Blood Song]]'' (1982). He also acted on television as well as the big screen, appearing in ''[[Search (TV series)|Search]]'' (1973), ''[[Strike Force (1975 film)|Strike Force]]'' (1975), which starred a young [[Richard Gere]],{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073758/|title=Strike Force|date=12 April 1975|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} ''[[Contract on Cherry Street]]''{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075876/|title=Contract on Cherry Street|date=19 November 1977|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} (1977), which featured [[Frank Sinatra]], ''[[Kojak]]'' (1978), and ''[[Magnum, P.I.]]''{{cite web|url=http://magnum-mania.com/Episodes/Season2/Italian_Ice.html |title=Episode Guide - Italian Ice |publisher=Magnum Mania! |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} (1982). Montana was usually cast as "muscle" for hire or an intimidating mobster. === Retirement and later life=== Montana retired from acting after appearing in the [[B movie]] ''[[Blood Song]]'' (1982), which he also co-wrote.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083660/fullcredits|title=Blood Song (1982)|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} He died May 12, 1992 of a [[heart attack]] in [[Lindenhurst, New York]]. He was 66 years old. His likeness was used as his character Luca Brasi in ''[[The godfather game|The Godfather Game]]''. Terence McGovern provided the voice acting.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0442674/fullcredits|title=The Godfather (Video Game 2006)|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} Montana was survived by his wife Sylvia, four children and twelve grandchildren. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{italictitle}} {{Taxobox | name = Lusius malfoyi | image =Lusius-malfoyi-lateral.jpg | image_upright = | image_alt = | image_caption = Lateral view | image2 = | image2_upright = | image2_alt = | image2_caption = | regnum = [[Animal]] | divisio = [[Arthropoda]] | classis = [[Insecta]] | ordo = [[Hymenoptera]] | familia = [[Ichneumonidae]] | genus = ''[[Lusius]]'' | species = ''L. malfoyi'' | binomial = ''Lusius malfoyi'' | binomial_authority = Saunders & Ward 2017 | range_map = | range_map_upright = | range map_alt = | range_map_caption = }} '''''Lusius malfoyi''''' is a [[parasitoid wasp]] found in [[New Zealand]]. The species is named for [[Lucius Malfoy]], a character in the fictional [[Harry Potter]] series of books by [[J.K. Rowling]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/10/new-zealand-wasp-named-harry-potter-character-lucius-malfoy/|title=New Zealand wasp named after Harry Potter character Lucius Malfoy|last=Pearlman|first=Jonathan|date=10 Oct 2017|website=The Telegraph|publisher=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114025328/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/10/new-zealand-wasp-named-harry-potter-character-lucius-malfoy/|archivedate=14 Jan 2018|dead-url=|accessdate=14 Jan 2018}}</ref><ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/10/lusius-malfoyi-wasp-new-zealand-insect-named-after-harry-potter-villain|title=Lusius malfoyi wasp: New Zealand insect named after Harry Potter villain|last=Roy|first=Elanor Ainge|date=10 Oct 2017|website=The Guardian|publisher=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119112845/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/10/lusius-malfoyi-wasp-new-zealand-insect-named-after-harry-potter-villain|archivedate=19 Oct 2017|dead-url=|accessdate=14 Jan 2018}}</ref>, although the genus was named in 1903 and was not named for this character. The species is the first in its genus described in New Zealand; although the [[holotype]] specimen was captured in 1981, it was not described until 2017. The species is geographically widespread but rare.<ref name = 'Saunders'>{{cite journal | first1 = Thomas E. | last1 = Saunders | first2 = Darren F. | last2 = Ward | title = A new species of ''Lusius'' (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) from New Zealand | journal = New Zealand Entomologist | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | date = 2017 | doi = 10.1080/00779962.2017.1357427 | pages = 72-78}}</ref>
== Description ==
The species is light brown or orange, with unbanded brown antennae. Female body length varies from 4.7 mm to 7.8 mm. Its coloration pattern, as well as its geographic range, distinguish it from other species in the genus. Its host, like that of other ''Lusius'' wasps, is unknown.<ref name='Saunders'/>
== Range ==
The species is known from both [[North Island|North]] and [[South Island|South Islands]] of New Zealand. It is not yet known from offshore islands or other locations, but this is likely due to a lack of sampling. Specimens were collected by [[malaise trap]] in spring to late summer (September through to March) in a wide range of habitats, in or near ''[[Nothofagus]]'' forests and other native forests and brush, from close to sea level up to 850 m.<ref name="Saunders" /> However very few specimens were collected from any one area, so the species appears to be naturally uncommon. It is the only member of the genus ''Lusius'' so far described from Australasia, though this may represent a lack of sampling.<ref name="guardian" />
== Etymology ==
The species was described by Thomas E. Saunders, then a Masters student at the [[University of Auckland]]. He chose the name in order to "redeem the reputation of wasps" in a manner similar to the redemption of Lucius Malfoy's character in the Harry Potter series.<ref name='guardian'/>
== See also == * [[List of organisms named after the Harry Potter series]]

The 1975 Showa Mechagodzilla is referenced as "Mechagodzilla 2" in Bandai's 2014 video game [[Godzilla (2014 video game)|''Godzilla'']], see [[Mechagodzilla#Video games|Video games]]}}
